title: mays brexit bodge 2021
story: As Brexit Secretary David Davis threatened to quit, the PM agreed to a “time-limited” plan where the UK would mirror EU customs rules after Brexit.But senior Government insiders admitted the new “cut-off” date was meaningless and unenforceable.And No 10 conceded Britain may be left on the hook for billions more in fees to the EU.Livid Tories demanded the PM press ahead with preparations for a “No Deal” Brexit given the deadlock over trade talks with Brussels.And former UKIP leader Nigel Farage said: “It is now time for all Brexiteers to resist.“This is clearly a recipe for keeping the UK inside the EU’s Customs Union and is completely unacceptable to all people who voted to leave the EU.”Meanwhile, as the Government descended into farce,It’s Alice in Wonderland stuff.”Britain is due to leave a post-Brexit transition phase at the end of 2020.The bitter row centred on a “backstop” plan with the EU that would take effect if a new customs system was not in place by then.Mrs May had insisted on a text that said the UK would mirror all current Brussels rules on customs indefinitely.Last night she refused to guarantee the backstop option will end by the date agreed with Mr Davis. She said: “The backstop is time limited. It may never be used.”In a letter to Tories, seen by The Times, even the PM called the UK proposal “unpalatable but at worst temporary” and “in no way the Government’s intended or desired” result.1000: Mrs May summons Liam Fox and Boris Johnson to test their views. The Brexiteers warn her she is risking a major upset if she does not back down.1030: Convinced Brexit ministers are on the verge of a mass walkout, No10 agrees to amend the backstop proposals to include a desire to end it by 2021 but in vague terms.1045: Mrs May sends her lieutenant Robbie Gibb to the Brexit department to hammer out a fudge.1100: Mrs May enrages David Davis by briefing journalists that a deal has already been done.1130: PM presents fudged words to David Davis who signs them off, averting his resignation. DD publishes statement declaring victory.1230: Theresa May’s war cabinet meet.1600: She flies to Canada, with aides spinning that she had pulled a fast one.PM Theresa May refused to give any guarantee that the backstop will end by the date she agreed with David Davis as her best expectation.Her defiant stand risks alarming Brexiteer Tory MPs afresh that Britain will be tied to EU customs rules for years to come.She was pressed twice on the way to the G7 summit in Canada for a guarantee that the backstop won’t last any longer than a year.But Mrs May would only say: “I have always been clear that the point about the back stop is it’s time limited, and it may never be used.“It only comes in if for technical reasons the agreed end state customs arrangement has not been possible to bring into place by 1st of January 2021.“As we’ve said today, we expect that end state customs arrangement at the latest will be in by December 2021, and we’ll be working to make sure it’s in earlier than that.”Mrs May also denied that Brexiteer Cabinet ministers Boris Johnson and Liam Fox were livid with her for trying to railroad the backstop decision through without a specifically stated time limit.Quizzed on if she had tried to deceive them, the PM hit back: “No. We’ve agreed previously the nature and structure of the backstop”.A senior Government source said Mr Davis had been “bambooz­led”. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dog thief cruella de vil king charles spaniels
story: Bridget Darling, 40 — who has two-tone hair and wears a fur coat like the 101 Dalmatians villain — was nabbed with 11 King Charles spaniels in her three-bed semi.She and husband Barry, 51, were also involved in the theft of at least four more pooches — in cahoots with Barbara Petrie-Harrison, 45, and her lover Craig Jackson, 42.Petrie-Harrison had bought a spaniel from breeder Madeline Cowling but later broke into her property in Market Rasen, Lincs, with Jackson to steal 15 dogs worth £6,500.The spaniels — one of which was pregnant — were then passed on to Barry Darling in Birstall, West Yorks.But cops were able to connect a car seen on CCTV in the area — a black Vauxhall Astra — to the Darlings.The investigation following the theft in September 2015 led to the arrest of all four.Judge Andrew Easteal ridiculed the defendants at Lincoln crown court, saying: “Let’s be clear, this was as deplorable and awful as it was amateurish and doomed to fail.“The speed it was detected and identified was almost embarrassingly fast.”Both Darlings admitted handling stolen property. Petrie-Harrison and Jackson, of Basingstoke, admitted burglary.They all got suspended prison sentences of between 12 and 16 months.But despite the convictions, the dogs could not be returned to their owner because they did not have microchips.Ms Cowling said: “This is two years later and I am still very anxious. I just wish they could tell me where my babies are.“Even though they were kennelled, they were very much loved. I just want my dogs back.”Earlier this year, analysis of crime stats by an insurance firm put Lincolnshire as the dog theft capital of Britain.Another breeder from the county said: “People watch 101 Dalmatians and Cruella de Vil and think it is only a movie, but this is happening in real life.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit sell out david davis sun says
story: The Government intends to offer the EU a “backstop” arrangement that could shackle us to its restrictive ­customs rules for ever to resolve the over-hyped Irish border issue.Brexit Secretary David Davis managed to get an end-date inserted, December 2021, but it was fudged as a mere “expectation”. It is not legally binding.It is supposedly temporary. But that is naïve. It gives the EU no incentive to negotiate the free trade deal we want.They will have us where they want us. They can reject Irish solutions for ever.We would be stuck,  unwillingly locked into their customs rules — but now with no say over them.No meaningful external trade deals. No full independence. Brexit’s key  economic argument destroyed. Without having prepared the country to walk away with “no deal”, what could we do?No wonder Remainers are cock-a-hoop.Is there embarrassment in No10? Or fear? No. Just GLEE, that Theresa May had stitched up Davis with the wooliness of the wording. “She’s done him like a kipper again,” said one source.It’s not the Brexit Secretary done up like a kipper. It’s Brexit and 17.4million voters. Mrs May must stand up for them. All we see is capitulation.AMAZON is creating 2,500 jobs. Fantastic — except House of Fraser is cutting 6,000. And 5,300 could go at Poundworld.Look no further for an illustration of the carnage on our high streets and the main reason why.Our stores simply cannot cope  with the cheap online competition alongside the sky-high business rates  on their premises.Before long our towns may only house restaurants, coffee shops, nail bars, barbers and tattooists. To retain a vibrant mix, stores need a level playing field.Which means far lower taxes for them. And Amazon paying every penny they owe.THE Tories need to stop swallowing the line that taxes must rise to fund the NHS.The sole reason the public seems prepared to pay more, as a poll indicates, is that both the Tories and Labour have convinced them it’s the only solution.It isn’t. Tax hikes should be a last resort. Government waste is still vast. So is the insane aid budget. Cut those first.The Tories cannot win votes posing as a saner version of Corbyn’s Labour. They should be unshakeable defenders of low taxes to boost the economy.Raising the overall burden beyond its  30-year high is political suicide, no matter the cause.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: parental advice alarm clocks sleeping tips
story: Prof Adam Joinson said teenagers lack the cognitive skills to realise that staying up all night using their mobile would mean being tired at school the next day.And he said those who rely on their phone’s alarm to wake should instead use a traditional one.Prof Joinson said he and his 17-year-old son had endless fights about the lad’s device being in his room at night — and he had banned its use there until he is 18.He told a Cheltenham Science Festival event: “Parents should take the phones off their kids at night. Store the charger downstairs and buy cheap alarm clocks.“Young people do not have the ability until they are in their 20s to fully understand consequences tomorrow of actions now.“This is a basic developmental thing and cognitively they cannot do it.“As parents we have a responsibility of care.Parents are remiss if they allow their kids to keep phones in their bedrooms.”The University of Bath academic also said those who rely on smartphone technology had “effectively outsourced their analytic thinking to Google or Siri or to Alexa”. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ecstasy mdma powder strongest ever uk
story: There are fears the dangerous high-strength drugs are being peddled to young revellers ahead of the festival season, putting lives at risk.The warning comes after two people died at the Mutiny Festival just last month where people were thought to have taken Green Heineken ecstasy pills.Michael Linnell, coordinator of the Greater Manchester Drug Early Warning System, told The Independent: MDMA pills and MDMA powder are stronger than they have ever been. This is what makes it so dangerous.Even half a pill can be a dangerously high dose on its own and the risk is increased if alcohol and other drugs are taken at the same time.He warned some pills contained 300mg of MDMA - three times a strong dose for an adult male.Super-strength ecstasy alone caused the deaths of more than 60 people in England and Wales in 2016.Police across the UK have already shared stark warnings against taking illicit substances, stressing the dangers of taking pills with unknown ingredients.Hampshire Police have launched an investigation into the deaths of Georgia Jones, 18, and Tommy Cowan, 20, after the pair died while attending Mutiny Festival.Festival organisers issued an urgent warning about super-strength drugs circulating the campsite before cancelling the second day of the event, attended by tens of thousands of people.Parklife festival, in Heaton, Manchester, shared a photo from drugs testing NGO The Loop to warn revellers, saying a VERY strong batch of pills were in circulation.The festival’s official Twitter account posted: “No doubt you have seen in the press about two very sad tragedies at a festival over the weekend.“There is a VERY strong batch of pills in circulation, with strength over 330mg.“These tablets, along with others, can result in death. Please act responsibly &amp look after each other.”The Loop is an NGO that campaigns for and provide drug safety testing at music festivals.Blue Punisher ecstasy pills the group tested in Bristol last week were found to contain 300mg of MDMA, more than three times the normal dose in a pill.Other tablets found by The Loop included “Silver” ecstasy which could contain up to four times the regular dose.A third heart shaped pill was said to contain pentylone instead of MDMA which can cause insomnia and paranoia for anywhere between 12 and 48 hours.West Yorkshire Police also issued a warning to the public about the dangers of drugs after officers stopped a group of teens in the town of Castleford in Wakefield on June 5.Two girls were arrested on public order offences before being taken to hospital, and a 13-year-old boy was later arrested in connection with drugs-related offences.It is believed the young girls had taken Snapchat pills.West Yorkshire Police said the two girls had since been released from hospital, with no further action taken after their arrests. The teen boy was also released under investigation.The force tweeted: We want to remind the public about the dangers of drugs. Drugs are often given catchy names to appeal to young people. Other festivals have taken to extraordinary lengths to ensure the safety of music fans.Dorsets Bestival announced it will offer on site drug testing at the festival.A spokesperson said: Bestival strongly advises festival goers to avoid taking any illegal substances.However, harm reduction and customer welfare are our priorities, so we have made the decision to bring The Loop onboard to offer drug safety testing onsite, giving people the opportunity to make informed choices.

title: biker lorry run over head back wheels
story: In the footage, the moped rider falls and becomes trapped in the path of the back wheels of the truck - and although his helmet is crushed, he appears to be unscathed.Filmed earlier this week in Cainta, Philippines, the biker is in a line of traffic when he attempts to pass the lorry on its right side.But as he overtakes, the moped appears to clip the kerb and the bike shudders before toppling to its side - tossing its rider in the path of the lorrys back wheels.Thrown face first to the road, the biker is trapped momentarily by the wheels as it rolls over his head.As traffic slows around them, he then makes several attempts to stand up.Although his helmet is almost flattened, miraculously, the biker appears to be unscathed.The clip, which was filmed by a vehicle travelling behind them, then shows the other moped riders rally around the man and manage to stop the lorry.He removes his green helmet and manages to stand up and - although he appears dazed - he stumbles to the footpath and kneels beside his bike.

title: schoolgirl 11 becomes one of uks youngest entrepreneurs by opening a diner
story: The ambitious schoolgirl designed every part of the restaurant, from the décor to the menu, inspired by her entrepreneur dad Matt Haycox who started his first business at 15.Harlie was influenced by her time spent living in Las Vegas where, at the age of nine, she created her own holiday-themed milkshakes for the family business Sticks and Shakes.She said: “When we were in Las Vegas, we would import English chocolate bars because they were much harder to find and everyone loved them.“My favourite flavour of milkshake is Dime bar, but I also really like Oreo-flavoured desserts.”Harlie’s Diner has a hot pink colour scheme, a menu which features American classics like hot wings, waffles and shakes, and even has fuchsia chopper bikes to make deliveries to the people of Leeds.Harlie enlisted help from her school friends to sample the menu and select the best flavours for the US-inspired meals and shakes.The restaurant is family-friendly but, like the diners she visited in Vegas, it stays open until six a.m. on weekends to cater to the local nightlife.Harlie’s father, Matt, 37, is the co-founder of Harlie’s Diner and primary investor of his daughter’s new venture and is happy to pass on his business know-how.Harlie said: “My dad has taught me a lot about using social media to grow a business, so I’m really getting the hang of it.“I’ve become a bit of an Amazon and eBay expert, finding all sorts of fun, neon signs to put up on the walls of the diner.“I’ve used this and Instagram to help bring the diner to life, encouraging customers to snap pictures and use hashtags.“I’m really pleased with my most recent purchase of two angel wings, that you can stand in between and take pictures of yourself in front of them.”Her dad is proud, but is pleased to let his daughter take the lead with her new business.He said:  “It’s a really exciting opportunity for Harlie and I’m thrilled to see her take the reins and spearhead the business. It seems entrepreneurialism is in the family DNA.“I didn’t start my first business until I was 15, so Harlie’s streets ahead of me, and has that instinct for what people will like that any good entrepreneur needs.“I’ll always be on hand to offer my advice, but it’s nice to see her come into her own.”Harlie’s Diner is open seven days a week from 12pm, and more information can be found at www.iloveharlies.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: vicar gay romanian toyboy appear jeremy kyle show
story: Philip Clements, 79, wed Florin Marin, 24, after the couple met online - but the relationship turned sour when the young Romanian left the elderly man just months into their marriage.Mr Clements had sold his £215,000 home in Sandwich, Kent, to buy a flat in Bucharest in Romania, where Mr Marin is originally from.But when the pair split five months into their marriage, Mr Clements was penniless and homeless.The couple have now vowed to give their romance another shot - turning to Jeremy Kyle to sort out their problems.The TV show is known for its dramatic handling of family and relationship tensions, often using DNA tests to sort out tensions.It is unclear just what will be discussed on the show, which is expected to air on June 28.But Mr Clements had previously explained he wanted to give his young lover another chance, despite claims that the younger man had moved on.The 79-year-old explained: “I have got to be realistic. I am 80 in August and I want to see him secure.He is the only one I can leave things to.He added he didnt think the young man was after his money, saying: I don’t see much of my brothers, and they wouldn’t need it.If it goes well, he will be in my will.The couple had tied the knot in April last year at a low-key ceremony in Ramsgate, KentA body language expert had previously weighed in on the couples relationship, saying the vicar had been blinded by love after seeing photographs of the couples wedding.Judi James, author of Body Language Bible, said: The phrase Love is blind has probably never been better illustrated than by the body language in these poses.ITV has been approached for comment.Mr Clements and Mr Marin will appear on The Jeremy Kyle Show on Thursday, June 28.

title: austria islam crackdown close mosques expel imams
story: Chancellor Sebastian Kurz said the government is shutting a hardline Turkish nationalist mosque in Vienna and dissolving a group called the Arab Religious Community that runs six mosques.The actions by the government are based on a 2015 law that prevents religious communities from getting funding from abroad.Interior Minister Herbert Kickl said the residence permits of around 40 imams employed by ATIB, a group that oversees Turkish mosques in Austria, are being reviewed because of concerns about such financing.Kickl said that, in two cases, permits have already been revoked, and five more imams were denied first-time permits.The conservative Kurz became chancellor in December in a coalition with the anti-migration Freedom Party.In campaigning for last years election, both coalition parties called for tougher immigration controls, quick deportations of asylum-seekers whose requests are denied and a crackdown on radical Islam.The government recently announced plans to ban girls in elementary schools and kindergartens from wearing headscarves, adding to existing restrictions on veils.Chancellor Kurz told reporters: Parallel societies, political Islam and tendencies toward radicalisation have no place in our country.He added that the governments powers to intervene were not sufficiently used in the past.The measures are a first significant and necessary step in the right direction, said Vice Chancellor Heinz-Christian Strache, the Freedom Partys leader.If these measures arent enough, we will if necessary evaluate the legal situation here or there.Austrias move angered the government in Turkey, where President Recep Tayyip Erdogans spokesman said the decision is a reflection of the Islamophobic, racist and discriminatory wave in this country.It is an attempt to target Muslim communities for the sake of scoring cheap political points,spokesman Ibrahim Kalin wrote on Twitter.He added that the Austrian governments ideologically charged practices are in violation of universal legal principles, social integration policies, minority rights and the ethics of co-existence.

title: eu theresa may michel barnier northern ireland brexit backstop plan
story: No10 issued a quick slap-down today after the EUs Brexit poured cold water on her plans to avoid a hard border on the island of Ireland after we leave the EU.As Mrs Mays day turned from bad to worse this lunchtime, Mr Barnier insisted that her backstop plans raise more questions than it provides and rubbished the idea of an end-date of the agreement.Mr Barnier argued that checks on ferries crossing between Northern Ireland and the UK in the event of the back-up plans being needed would be much less disruptive than checks along a 500km land border.That would effectively put the border back in the Irish sea - something which has already been thrown out by Britain and Northern Ireland.Mrs Mays Government partners, the DUP, would never agree to anything which separates them from the mainland.No10 hit back with a furious statement, insisting Mrs May would never do anything to split up the UK.A spokesperson said:  The Prime Minster has been clear that we will never accept a customs border between Northern Ireland and the rest of the United Kingdom.And the DUP were also fuming, saying Mr Barniers latest demands for Northern Ireland shows they have no respect for the UK at all.Deputy DUP leader Nigel Dodds stormed: This is nothing more than an outrageous attempt to revert to the annexation of Northern Ireland.We will not accept such a proposal.Instead he said the focus should be on getting a trade deal, and to forget about the back up plans altogether.The EUs chief Brexit negotiator caused chaos this afternoon when he appeared to throw out Britains Northern Ireland backstop plans altogether.He was originally thought to have said that there was no way the plans for the whole of the UK would be acceptable - but then clarified later in a tweet that he was talking about his own plans.This is not a rejection of the UK customs paper on which discussions continue, he added.Elsewhere in his press conference, Mr Barnier stormed in an angry rant: When we tell them, our British counterparts, that these benefits are not accessible outside the system created and this is the result of them deciding to leave, some try to make us responsible for the consequence of that decision.We are not going to be intimidated by this form of blame game. The UK has decided to leave the EU - we respect that and are implementing that, but the UK has to accept that has consequences.And he called on Britain to show more trust and realism in ongoing talks with the bloc.Mr Barnier said the option to keep Northern Ireland inside the EUs customs union was an exceptional one and that nothing like it had ever been agreed before.But he did say he was willing to talk to find a solution.Mrs May hit back immediately to Mr Barniers comments, saying she would never compromise the unity of the UK.That position will not change. The Commission’s proposals did not achieve this, which is why we have put forward our own backstop solutions for customs.All parties must recall their commitment in the Joint Report to protect the Belfast Agreement in all its parts.Michel Barnier has confirmed today that discussions will now continue on our proposal.The news comes just hours after it emerged that Boris Johnson had lashed out at Remainers in the cabinet, spilling Mrs Mays top team into an open civil war.The Foreign Secretary described the Treasury as the heart of Remain and warned of a meltdown in EU negotiations to come.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the queen eye surgery remove cataract sunglasses
story: The 92-year-old monarch underwent the successful procedure in May.In recent weeks, she has been seen wearing sunglasses at a number of events including the Royal Windsor Horse Show and Buckingham Palace garden parties.According to The Press Association she was treated as a day patient at the private King Edward VIIs hospital in London.A Buckingham Palace spokesman said: I can confirm that the Queen successfully underwent a short planned procedure to treat a cataract last month.And, it was business as usual for the head of state, who did not cancel or postpone any engagements.Cataracts are when the lens, a small transparent disc inside the eye, develops cloudy patches.Over time these patches usually become bigger causing blurry, misty vision and eventually blindness, if left untreated.Cataracts are more common in the elderly and can affect the ability to carry out daily activities such as driving.A family history of cataracts can increase the risk of developing them.The Queen Mother had an operation to remove a cataract from her left eye in 1995 when she was 95 but, unlike her daughter, she spent a night in King Edward VIIs Hospital after the surgery.The Queen, who is in good health, is known for her robust constitution.In 2013, she had her first hospital stay in 10 years when, at the age of 86, she suffered symptoms of gastroenteritis and missed an engagement in Swansea.A week of engagements, including a two-day trip to Rome, was cancelled and the Queen spent one night in hospital.Surgery to remove and replace the affected lens with an artificial one is the most common surgical procedure carried out on the NHS.Around 390,000 cataract surgeries take place each year in England and 16,000 in Wales, according to the eye research charity Fight for Sight.The condition most commonly affect adults as a result of ageing.Most people start to develop cataracts after the age of 65, but some people in their forties and fifties can also develop them.Cataracts, which can affect one or both eyes, are a major cause of sight loss.But the surgery is a straightforward procedure that usually takes 30 to 45 minutes.It is often carried out as day surgery under local anaesthetic, meaning the patient can go home the same day.She usually attends hospital for an annual routine check-up.Cataract surgery involves replacing the cloudy lens inside the eye with an artificial one.It is the most common operation performed in the UK, with a high success rate in improving eyesight.The straightforward procedure usually takes 30 to 45 minutes.During the operation, the surgeon will make a tiny cut in the eye to remove the cloudy lens and replace it with a clear plastic one.It is often carried out as day surgery under local anaesthetic and patients usually go home on the same day.It can take four to six weeks to recover.

title: i sold my innocent picture to a stock image site for 50 and now im the face of bestiality
story: But what happens when those pictures end up in places you hadnt even imagined - such as alongside an article declaring how youre turned on by orgies with fat, old men or holding a placard saying youre a sex offender?Becoming the poster boys and girls for such causes is a far cry from where those posing for inoffensive stock images - used in newspapers, magazines and adverts when no suitable pics are available - believe theyll end up.This week, a Twitter thread went viral after stock models shared their accounts of the hilarious and surprising campaigns they had been linked to, following @marleybennett joke that he looked like the model on a tobacco warning label.Here, they share their faces bizarre final destinations.First to respond was Yair Kivaiko who was surprised to find his photo on an article about bestiality last year after uploading the image to a stock photo site.The 36-year-old product manager, told Sun Online: It was just a photo Id taken for fun with my parents dogs in their back yard about four or five years ago and I decided to sell it via an app online to make some extra cash.I was mortified when I saw it on an article about bestiality.It took me a really long time to tell my friends and family what had happened. I would never want to be recognised as that guy by people that had read the article.But despite the questionable associations, Yair doesnt regret selling the photo.I love the picture and enjoy seeing it from time-to-time on other ads, he says.I could have done without the bestiality story, but it was a minor website and luckily the article is no longer available online so theres no real harm done. I wasnt sure how to react at first, but today I look at it as a funny turn of events and laugh about it.Niccolò Massariello, a Spanish writer for Vice, revealed how his stock photos ended up on adverts for booze, milk, the Catholic Church and even paraphimosis  - a horrifying penis condition in which the foreskin gets trapped behind the tip of the penis.Following a tricky break up, Niccolò embarked on an impulsive photoshoot with a mate to try and take his mind off stuff, and signed away his rights to the images without realising the potential repercussions.He discovered his images had been sold months later when he saw his face on an article about terrorists on a Catholic website.“That in itself wasnt so bad, but it was then that I realised I had no control over what might happen to my face,” he told Vice.In the following months, Niccolò’s face was used to promote anything and everything, from gluten-free drinks and Columbian spirits to articles on vindictive exes and “jerks” at work.Things then went from bad to worse, with Niccolò finding his increasingly-popular face on the cover of a book about monsters, an advert for shaving, and, finally, on national campaign about a very serious penis problem in Venezuela.As I was getting up one morning a friend from Venezuela asked me on Whatsapp if I had – or had ever had – paraphimosis, a very serious penis issue, he explained.I told my friend that I might have had some issues down there in the past, but that I dont remember it being called that.Nicos friend then informed him that he was the poster boy for paraphimosis in Venezuela.I know I cant really complain – I was fully conscious when I had those pictures taken and I actively signed away the rights to my face, he says.Still, that doesnt mean I dont rue the day I posed for those pictures. Briefly feeling a little better about myself that day does not compare to the fact I have no idea where my face will show up next.Like many others in her situation, Samantha Ovens stock image modelling shots - which were originally taken for a campaign on cold and flu medication - were used for something she could never have imagined.Samantha, who is gay, was out with her friends when she was first alerted to the fact that her face had been used on article, titled: “I fantasise about group sex with old, obese men,” on the s anonymous sex column.The piece, written in first person, explained how the author, a 31-year-old woman, struggled with fantasies about being “passed around” by fat, ugly old men.“The thing that really turns me on is the idea of having to lift their stomachs and search for their penises, which are always difficult to find and a bit on the soft side,” is just one of the graphic lines in the first paragraph which Samantha’s image was next to.Luckily, the successful model, who usually specialises in portraying mums on shoot, found the whole thing hilarious.I was with my partners mum [when I first saw it], Samantha told the  later. I screeched with laughter and said: Oh. You have to see this.“How can you take it seriously? There are bigger things in this life to get concerned about.In a much more serious case, a British family’s image was used on a poster campaign by an Irish group opposing gay marriage ahead of the 2015 referendum - a campaign which they strongly disagreed with.In an anonymous interview with the BBC, the family said they were given a free photo shoot in exchange for allowing the photographer to sell the images on.The photo was not stolen from us... we have no claim over (or rights to) the picture, and we do not claim otherwise, the family said.We just wanted publicly to say that we disagreed with the No campaign and were unhappy about their use of our image, but we acknowledge that theyre allowed to do so.Other examples of awkwardly-placed stock images include Simon Naylors face on an article about Viagra which was pointed out to him in his local pub.Thought nothing of signing over a few headshots for use as stock images, until my local pub landlord spotted me in Take A Break, he tweeted.But we dont think its quite as bad as this poor girls holiday snap being used as an advert for colonic procedures.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: amazon prime plays the premier league game
story: The company puts great store by encouraging more and more people to sign up for its Prime package, which involves paying an annual fee in exchange for next-day delivery on purchases, as well as television and film content.And these matches will only be available to people with a Prime account.It was the same logic that led Amazon to sign up the Top Gear team - an eye-catching deal, that can be marketed heavily and bring in new subscribers.Expect a big campaign to persuade you to spend most of Boxing Day watching football with the family, which may delight some and horrify others.Amazon gets to put its toe in the water, which has led plenty to speculate that, next time round, the company will return with plans to buy a huge chunk of rights. Right now, I doubt that.The billions of pounds that it would take to buy the British television rights simply wouldn't return an investment for them, Google, Apple, or any other global tech player.What might attract them more are the international rights.That's also the area with the greatest scope for growth and, by coincidence, today was also the day when the Premier League announced it was changing the way that the revenue would be divided up from its global deals.More will now go the big six clubs, who have successfully argued that they provide the panache and stardust that attracts viewers, from Thailand to Tajikistan.That's a decision with the potential to shake top-flight football even more profoundly than the arrival of Amazon.

title: michel barniers jibe at pm as brexit impasse on irish border remains
story: The current deadlock on the Irish border stems from Mrs May's rejection of the EU's own proposal for a backstop solution earlier this year, which saw Brussels propose Northern Ireland effectively remaining within a customs union with the EU after Brexit.This is in the event that a wider EU-UK agreement does not prevent a hard border on the island of Ireland.The prime minister, under pressure from her DUP allies at Westminster, told Brussels its plan was unacceptable as it would threaten the "constitutional integrity" of the UK.This prompted Thursday's counter-proposal from Mrs May, which suggests the UK as a whole remaining in a temporary customs arrangement with the EU for a time-limited period.At Friday's press conference, Mr Barnier insisted the EU's proposal for a backstop "cannot be extended to the whole UK" as it was "designed for the specific situation of Northern Ireland".He said: "What is feasible with a territory the size of Northern Ireland is not necessarily feasible with the whole UK." Mr Barnier also dismissed the UK's proposal for a time-limited arrangement, saying: "This has to be a backstop that provides a guarantee under all circumstances... unless and until we find a solution."That is why the time-limited terminology doesn't work for us."In response to Mr Barnier's comments, a UK government spokesperson reiterated the prime minister's view that she will "never accept a customs border between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK".They added: "We are also committed to maintaining the integrity of our own internal market. That position will not change."The Commission's proposals did not achieve this, which is why we have put forward our own backstop solutions for customs. All parties must recall their commitment in the Joint Report to protect the Belfast Agreement in all its parts."Michel Barnier has confirmed today that discussions will now continue on our proposal."The DUP's deputy leader Nigel Dodds accused Mr Barnier of "an outrageous attempt to revert to the annexation of Northern Ireland" and claimed the EU official demonstrated "no respect for the principle of consent or the constitutional integrity of the UK". He urged Mr Barnier to instead focus on agreeing a EU-UK trade deal.Labour's pro-Remain MP Ian Murray, a supporter of the People's Vote campaign for another EU referendum on the final Brexit deal, claimed Mr Barnier's stance showed Mrs May's "flimsy Brexit proposal has lasted less than 24 hours".

title: car seat safety advice every
story: AdvertorialThe car seat safety advice every parent needs to know about, including the latest rules and lawsIn a car or on a bike, no matter how your kids are getting around this summer it's important to make sure they're safe&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByHolly Thatcher14:53, 8 JUN 2018Updated15:19, 8 JUN 2018AdvertorialEnsure your kids are safe by investing in the right equipment, from car seats to bike helmets&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWith 12 children under 10 either killed or injured in cars every day the matter of safety is crucial for any parent. Unless your child is taller than 135cm or over the age of 12 then they legally need to be in a car seat. And quite apart from the law, kids' car seats save lives and prevent serious injuries. When riding a bike it's important to have the right safety gear too. Although there is no legal requirement to wear a helmet, recent research shows that wearing one significantly reduces the risk of sustaining a head injury. Child Safety Week is designed to help parents and carers understand how best to keep kids safe and Halfords has an amazing range of bike and car equipment that will help. From car seats to bike lights there's lots of gear to keep your little ones safe on the road and lots of in-store expert advice to help you fit what you buy. Car safety: Babies and toddlers    Very small children need additional protection and modern car seats offer a lot of features to keep your baby as safe as possible – for example, extra neck and head supports mean that they are protected in an impact. The Joie Spin 360 is versatile. It can be rear-facing for infants up to 9kg and switched to forward-facing for kids between 9 and 18kg. It rotates so you can get your baby out of the car easily and it has five recline settings for both forward and rear-facing modes. ISOFIX compliance means it mounts to hard anchors in your car for maximum safety. Car safety: Older kids  Once your kids weigh more than 15kg they need a group 2-3 booster seat. These are adjustable to allow your children to use them up until 12 years or a weight of 36kg. After that weight, they can rely on normal car seatbelts. The Joie Trilo Inkewell has washable seat covers (crucial, given the amount of time they're used for and how messy little ones can be) and offer side impact protection and an adjustable headrest. There's even a cupholder! If you don't have ISOFIX mounts in your car then the Halfords Highback Booster Seat offers excellent protection and are secured by the car's seatbelt. There's an included cupholder, washable cover and adjustable headrest. It also has side impact protection too, as you'd expect.  Halfords also has an in-store car seat demo and fitting service too, which will help you learn how the seats need to be fitted and ensure they’re compatible with your car. Car safety: High-backed or backless boosters There are two different kinds of booster seat on the market. High-backed tend to have more advantages which include supporting a child’s head, allowing them to sleep and protecting them in an accident. High-backed seats also help to keep the seatbelt correctly positioned on children, especially smaller kids. Backless booster seats are, on the whole, cheaper though and may suit older and larger children slightly more than those with backs. Bike safety: helmets    The first thing any young cyclist needs is a helmet. Young kids might like to choose a fun design and Halfords has Polka Dots , princesses , stars or even an absolutely awesome skull design, along with a range of fun colours. Prices start at &pound10. Older kids might like the Mongoose Urban Helmet, which looks cool and offers excellent protection. It's also available in either black and white, to suit their style. Halfords has a great range of helmets and in-store experts can help you find the right helmet for your little one. Bike safety: Being seen

title: 5 most explosive things boris
story: NewsAnalysisBoris Johnson's 5 most explosive claims at a leaked private dinner - and why they're so unprofessionalThe Foreign Secretary has been secretly recorded boasting about Brexit, Trump and North Korea. Here are the comments that will damage him most - and why&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDan BloomPolitical reporter09:38, 8 JUN 2018Updated10:02, 8 JUN 2018NewsAnalysisVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMop-headed Boris Johnson has been plunged into a political storm that's pretty incredible - even by Boris's standards. The Foreign Secretary has been secretly recorded boasting to right-wing Tory activists about Brexit, Trump and North Korea at a private dinner. Leaked to BuzzFeed News and The Times, the remarks are embarrassing at best. And at worst they're not only deeply unprofessional - they undermine the entire govenrment. Mr Johnson steamrollered Theresa May's Brexit plan and campaigned hard for his own vision in the address to Conservative Way Forward.  He ridiculed warnings about Brexit as pure millennium bug stuff, dismissed official claims his customs plan will cost &pound20bn a year, and said: I'm not going to hide it from you, there is an argument. A lot of this isn't surprising - and Tory MP Gerald Howarth today even said the tape serves a valuable purpose for Brexiteers. But some of his comments went much, much further. Here we analyse the most eye-popping bits of what Boris said - and why it could come back to bite him. 1. Donald Trump should do Brexit  What he said: Boris said he is “increasingly admiring of Donald Trump and more and more convinced that there is method in his madness...Trump to negotiate Brexit , what a fantastic idea... Imagine Trump doing Brexit. He’d go in bloody hard. There’d be all sorts of breakdowns, all sorts of chaos. Everyone would think he’d gone mad. But actually you might get somewhere. It’s a very, very good thought.” Why it's a problem: This exposes the way Boris thinks - preferring chaos to his boss's 'strong and stable' mantra. It inflates the US President's large ego just as the world is supposed to be taking him down a peg over steel tariffs. And it's a direct attack on Theresa May, suggesting she's inferior to another world leader and not getting anywhere with her Brexit talks. 2. Brexit will trigger a meltdown and the EU is the 'enemy'  What he said: “I think Theresa is going to go into a phase where we are much more combative with Brussels. You’ve got to face the fact there may now be a meltdown. OK? I don’t want anybody to panic during the meltdown. No panic. Pro bono publico, no bloody panic. It’s going to be all right in the end.... Take the fight to the enemy - absolutely right. We need to and we will. Why it's a problem: It's utterly extraordinary that a minister is admitting his own strategy will trigger a 'meltdown' and could cause 'panic'. It's also hugely damaging to Theresa May's constant efforts to tell Brussels she's approaching Brexit talks in a co-operative way. Describing the EU as the 'enemy' is a definite no-no from the UK's top diplomat. 3. The 'heart of Remain' Treasury is a 'quivering wreck'  What he said: The Treasury, which is basically the heart of Remain... What they don’t want is friction at the borders. They don’t want any disruption of the economy. So they’re sacrificing all the medium and long-term gains out of fear of short-term disruption. Do you see what I'm saying? The fear of short-term disruption has become so huge in people’s minds that they’ve turned into a quivering wreck. The Project Fear is irreversible! They’re terrified of this nonsense! It’s mumbo jumbo. Why it's a problem: Again, it is extraordinary for a serving government minister to attack his own government like this. It's no secret that the Treasury, under Chancellor Philip Hammond, is pro-Remain. But here is Boris attacking civil servants too as terrified and quivering wrecks. It's certainly not in the spirit of collective responsibility, where each minister is meant to agree publicly with the whole government. And it's likely to sour relations even more between warring Cabinet ministers. 4. US has asked him to dismantle Kim's nuclear missile  What he said: Of course we’ve got to help the Americans do this thing…. I just talked to Mike Pompeo, my counterpart in the US State Department. What they want us to do is to use our nuclear expertise to dismantle Kim Jong-Un’s nuclear missile. That’s what he asked me to do today.” Why it's a problem: North Korea, of course, knows Britain wants it to dismantle nuclear weapons. But usually talks between allies are conducted in private with only brief summaries provided to the media. Civil servants who work on national security go through exhaustive background checks and are given firm instructions not to talk about their work. This kind of highly sensitive detail is an extraordinary thing to be casually revealing to activists at a private dinner. 5. Britain has a G7 plan to take on Russia

story: NewsopinionJeremy Corbyn: We must join G7 leaders in standing up to Trump – for our workersWhen the leaders of the world’s richest countries meet today in Canada, Britain will need our Prime Minister to stand up for the country’s workforce&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByJeremy Corbyn00:29, 8 JUN 2018NewsopinionCorbyn says Donald Trump's tariffs are simply wrong (Image: REUTERS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWe must join G7 leaders in standing up to Trump – for our workers and industry. When the leaders of the world’s richest countries meet today in Canada, Britain will need our Prime Minister to stand up for the country’s workforce. The UK’s steel industry and its 32,000 employees are under threat from President Donald Trump’s reckless decision to jack up tariffs on steel, and Theresa May must take a lead at the summit in calling him out. The Trump tariffs are simply wrong.  They are bad news for British workers and industry. They are also bad news for US workers and industry. It is vital that all the leaders come together to condemn the Trump tariffs. We need to stop the escalation of a tit-for-tat trade war that can only be bad news for all workers and businesses. As I told the GMB trade union conference in Brighton this week, US workers are right to want a government that actively supports them and the real, everyday economy.  But the Trump tariffs don’t do that. And neither does the Trump agenda of giving handouts to the super-rich, while propping up a rigged system that hoards power and wealth for a tiny elite. Whether it’s over Trump’s Muslim ban and his shameless promotion of the far right Britain First group, his dangerous decision to abandon the Paris Climate Accord or his wilful tearing up of the Iran nuclear deal, Theresa May has repeatedly shown she doesn’t have the courage to stand up for what we all know to be right.  The Tories want to appease Trump in the hope of getting a quick trade deal with the US after we leave the European Union. But what their reaction to the Trump tariffs show is that with the timid Tories in government, we’ll end up with worst kind of race-to-the-bottom deal. That would hurt workers, consumers and our public services.

story: NewsSafe standing at football matches officially backed by the Labour Party in major breakthroughCritics of the current rules point out many fans simply stand anyway and there are hopes a change could bring down spiralling ticket costs&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editorDan BloomPolitical reporter10:18, 8 JUN 2018NewsArsenal fan Jeremy Corbyn has approved the new Labour policy (Image: PA)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLabour today backed safe standing at football matches in a major breakthrough for campaigners. Supporters of teams in the top two divisions have been banned from standing at games since Lord Taylor's report into the 1989 Hillsborough disaster - in which 96 Liverpool fans died. But calls have been growing for restrictions to be eased to boost atmosphere. Critics of the current rules point out many fans simply stand anyway and there are hopes a change could bring down spiralling ticket costs. Labour today unveiled a new policy to let clubs, fans and safety authorities decide. Shadow Sports Minister Rosena Allin-Khan said: “Clubs, fans and local authorities know their stadium far better than anybody in Whitehall - the decision should rest with them.  This is about safety the current system isn't working, people are standing in unsafe seated areas and accidents can happen.  Labour's backing comes days after it emerged the government had begun talks with the Premier League and EFL over the possibility.  MPs will debate safe standing on 25 June after more than 100,000 fans called for the move in a petition. Labour's plan would cap the number of safe standing places at 7,500 per stadium, in line with Football League proposals. Ms Allin-Khan announced the policy after visiting Liverpool and holding private meetings with Hillsborough families, who are still split on whether to bring back standing.

story: NewsWoman loses five stone and gets 'revenge body' after ex taunted her for gaining weight due to contraceptionAlexandra Quadrelli sculpted the 'ultimate revenge body' after being called fat by her ex, who she claims cheated on her multiple times&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByJosh Saunders21:02, 7 JUN 2018Updated22:53, 7 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A woman who was told by a previous boyfriend she was overweight lost five stone in less than four months in desperate bid to keep her new man.  Alexandra Quadrelli sculpted the 'ultimate revenge body' after being called fat by her ex, who she claims cheated on her multiple times. The 29-year-old from Perth, Australia, was paranoid her partner would leave her when she bulged to 15st 6oz - about 98kg - after getting the contraceptive implant. Fearing her current partner would stop finding her attractive and battling depression because she hated her appearance, she started taking 123Diet Drops and a clean eating plan. In under four months the deli assistant, originally from Milan, Italy, shed a whopping five stone - more than 31kg - from sticking to the plan without exercising. Alexandra said: Before I felt bad, frustrated, ugly, unhappy and unhealthy. I constantly had the fear of going out and having a social life because I was scared others would judge me.  My life was constantly hiding my body under large clothing, I hid myself from everyone. I always loved going to the beach but when I was a heavier weight, I was too shy to wear a swimsuit or to go shopping because I was frustrated that there weren't suitable clothes for me. I was unhealthy, unhappy and I was so scared of losing my actual boyfriend because an ex-boyfriend was so rude to me, always cheated on me and would regularly tell me how fat I was.  So I told myself no, not this time. I started to take better care of myself because my health is more important and secondly, because I wanted my boyfriend look at me in different way. Now, I love my body, feel sexy and better about myself but more important than anything else, I'm healthy. I love myself more and my boyfriend sees me in a whole new way. I will always be grateful to 123Diet.  Now I have a revenge body for all the people who are discriminated against their weight I have a revenge body for my ex-boyfriend who was humiliated because of my appearance and to show myself I can do anything. Alexandra says she never struggled with weight problems in the past, until having a contraceptive implant and the stresses of moving to Australia three years ago. This led her to hit her heaviest weight when she had a BMI of 34.9.

story: NewsEasyjet calls for duty-free alcohol to be banned on flights after drunk man causes chaos on planeThe budget airline says "the major causal factor of disruption in the air" is caused by alcohol bought in airports being drunk on board planes&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByRachel Russell14:42, 8 JUN 2018NewsA man was arrested following disruptive behaviour on a plane (Image: The Journal)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn airline has called for a ban on duty-free alcohol being consumed on planes after a man was arrested for being drunk and disorderly during a flight. Spanish police took the man into custody when Easyjet flight EZY6089, from Bristol to Mahon, Menorca, touched down on the runway on Tuesday, June 5. Easyjet said the man behaved in a disruptive manner on board the flight after he had been drinking his own alcohol that had been purchased at Bristol Airport. A spokesperson told BristolLive the budget airline has been lobbying for a ban on the consumption of duty free alcohol on board flights for a long time.   EasyJet Prague stag-do party members 'abused staff, swore in front of kids and URINATED on toilet floor' before flight cancelled  The spokesperson said: Typically it is the alcohol consumed and/or bought in the airport that is the major causal factor of disruption in the air and so we strongly believe that two simple regulatory changes need to be made. The vast majority of passengers who consume alcohol in the airport or on board do so responsibly and we believe that these two measures would protect their interests while reducing the number of disruptive incidents and making flying safer and more enjoyable for all.  A flight from Bristol to Prague was cancelled earlier in the week after a group of men on a stag do treated the plane like a nightclub, as well as adverse weather conditions. story: NewsMidge misery as walker films himself covered in biting insects and others become 'prisoners' in their homesScott Sweeney shared a shocking video of hundreds of midges clinging to his hands and buzzing around him as Scots claim it's the "worst year ever" for the presence of the flies&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByAbbi GartonDanya BazaraaNews Reporter09:19, 8 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A walker has filmed himself covered in midges as the biting insects wreak havoc and cause people to become 'prisoners in their own homes'.  Scots are claiming it's the worst year ever so far for the presence of the ravenous flies in the country. Scott Sweeney, from Inveraray, Argyll and Bute, works outdoors as a deer manager says the midges make it difficult to get any work done. The 31-year-old shared a shocking video clip of hundreds of tiny midges clinging to his hands and buzzing around him as he sat on a hill with his dog Leah. The post gathered more than 1,400 likes and was shared at least 1,200 times as Scots warned each other to be prepared when hitting the outdoors.  Scott said: I would say the midges are worse than ever this year. They maybe started later as the winter lingered on a bit, but now they have arrived they have just exploded the last few weeks. He added: They are always bad, but I don't think I have ever seen this before in my life. They may well calm off, but at this exact moment, they are the worst ever. They may have arrived a little bit later due to an unusually cold start this year, but midges are back with a boom and terrorising Scots. Lucy Fraser, from Rowardennan, Stirling, says she has become a prisoner in her own home and revealed that a contractor was forced to stop laying new decking at her property because the midges were so bad. Dr Alison Blackwell, from the Scottish Midge Forecast, backed the claims and said that despite the slowest start to the midge season in three years - midge spray has been flying off the shelves this week as they reemerge.  Midges typically begin to come out during the end of May, and in June the female biting midges arrive to kick off the season. In 2017 a record number of 68 million midges descended on Scotland - a 40% rise on the year before - but experts have not revealed this years' estimated figures yet. However, Scots across the country have taken to social media to share their midge misery. Lucy Fraser runs her home as guest house for walkers taking on the West Highland way and has to give them a stern warning not to open the windows - or suffer the consequences. The 57-year-old posted a photograph of midges infiltrating a lamp outside of her home. In the space of last week hundreds of the tiny critters filled up the glass case almost to the halfway point. The hotelier said: I insist the guests don't open the windows. If they do it's horrific and believe me some do and regret it. Each year from the end of May to October I become a prisoner and wouldn't dare go out the door before 10am and after 5pm. This is when the midge is at its worst, the sun keeps them away but the rain attracts them. I've been here 22 years and it gets worse every year.  The mum-of-eight added: Trying to get tradesmen to work here between May and October is impossible as no one could work outdoors without being driven insane. I'm trying to have a deck area built and the guys said they have never seen anything as bad and even though I gave them a huge fan they said they had to abort the job. I've known these guys many years and they have done lots of work but just couldn't cope this year. They said it's first time ever he's had to leave a job due to midges. Social media users were quick to share their shock at the state of the midges already. Lynn Bindon said: A zombie apocalypse has nothing on Scotland's midge season. Stay safe people. Fiona Macdonald Fraser wrote: Ughhh! Gives me the fear.

The driver of the car was left with a cut from the knife and ended up in hospital. Anyone who either witnessed this crime, was in the area and has dashcam footage, or anyone with any information should contact police immediately. Your information could be vital in bringing these dangerous men to justice. Scotland Yard are appealing for information following the robbery and have released dashcam images of the incident. title: queen eye surgery last month
story: NewsQueen had eye surgery last month - and wore sunglasses at public events for weeks afterwardsThe Queen has continued to attend her commitments since the surgery, and has been spotted at a number of events wearing sunglasses&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByLaura Elston15:21, 8 JUN 2018Updated16:17, 8 JUN 2018NewsThe Queen in shades at a Buckingham Palace garden party (Image: PA)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Queen has managed to conceal her recent eye surgery to remove a cataract by wearing sunglasses at public events.  The 92-year-old monarch underwent the successful procedure in May, which if left untreated can cause blindness. In recent weeks, the Queen has been seen wearing sunglasses at a number of events including the Royal Windsor Horse Show and Buckingham Palace garden parties. The Queen was reportedly treated as a day patient at the private King Edward VII's hospital in London. When approached, a Buckingham Palace spokesman said: I can confirm that the Queen successfully underwent a short planned procedure to treat a cataract last month.  Cataracts are when the lens, a small transparent disc inside the eye, develops cloudy patches. Over time these patches usually become bigger causing blurry, misty vision and eventually blindness, if left untreated. Despite her recent surgery, it was business as usual for the head of state, who did not cancel or postpone any engagements. The Queen is known for her robust health. Her son the Duke of York once described her as being incredibly fit for her age, and the 92-year-old monarch still rides her Fell ponies at Windsor, and drives, mainly around her private estates.  The Queen's no fuss approach to injury and illness was perfectly illustrated in 1994. She broke her left wrist when her horse tripped during a ride on the Sandringham estate in Norfolk. The break was not diagnosed until almost 24 hours later when her arm was X-rayed and set in plaster at a hospital. It was the first time she had fallen in many years and the Queen had simply brushed herself down, remounted her horse and trotted on back to Sandringham. She has since called time on her overseas travels, leaving long-haul destinations to the younger members of her family. But she still has a busy diary of events, and in 2017 carried out 296 engagements.

title: queens honours list refused returned
story: NewsCelebrities that turned down Queen's Honours or returned them - from David Bowie to Roald DahlFor many, it is the greatest moment of their lives to be awarded an honour by the Queen - but for others, it clearly isn't&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByGreig Box-TurnbullJo-Anne RowneyAudience Growth Editor13:30, 8 JUN 2018Updated13:44, 8 JUN 2018NewsQueen Elizabeth II looks fed up after her horse Carlton House comes in third in the Epsom Derby (Image: Getty)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCelebrated authors, painters, actors and sportsmen are among the hundreds of people who have refused an honour from the Queen. From children's author Roald Dahl to film director Alfred Hitchcock, 277 people declined the Queen's Honours in the New Year or Birthday Honours lists from 1951 to 1999, the Cabinet Office confirmed in 2012. Since that official list of those who had declined honours were first published, it has become increasingly common for celebs to reveal their refusal. Before that, it had been relatively rare to do so. While people have explained their decision to turn down honours in many different ways, a number have cited the honours system’s links to empire. How do you refuse an honour? Nominees are asked by Downing Street if they will accept well in advance, and are usually able to reject the offer without going public. Several personalities said a polite ‘no’ to the Queen on more than one occasion. So who exactly has turned down the Birthday Honours, here we take a look at the big names who have rejected the award. Who has refused Birthday Honours? Back in 2003, a list of living celebs who had refused gongs had been leaked, including David Bowie and Helen Mirren (though she later accepted a damehood). French and Saunders  The comedy pairing turned down OBEs for services to comedy drama in 2001. It was only later they explained. Saunders said: “If I felt I deserved a Damehood I’d accept it,” she told Source magazine. “At the time, we felt that we were being paid very well to have a lot of fun. It didn’t seem right somehow. “We didn’t deserve a pat on the back. It felt a bit fake to stand alongside people who devoted their lives to truly worthy causes.” David Bowie  Bowie himself later explained his decision not to join the list of musical knights including Sir Mick Jagger, Sir Paul McCartney and Sir Elton John. He said: “I would never have any intention of accepting anything like that. I seriously don’t know what it’s for. It’s not what I spent my life working for.” When asked about Jagger accepting the honour, he said: “It’s not my place to make a judgment on Jagger, it’s his decision. But it’s just not for me.” Nigella Lawson  The celeb chef turned down the offer of an OBE in 2001, though it's not known why. Benjamin Zephaniah Poet Benjamin Zephaniah explained his public refusal in 2003. He wrote: “OBE, me? Up yours, I thought. I get angry when I hear that word ‘empire’: it reminds me of slavery, thousands of years of brutality.” “I am not one of those who are obsessed with their roots, and I’m certainly not suffering from a crisis of identity my obsession is about the future and the political rights of all people. “Benjamin Zephaniah OBE - no way Mr Blair, no way Mrs Queen. I am profoundly anti-empire.” Stephen Hawking  In 2008 Hawking said he had been approached with an offer of a knighthood in the late 1990s, but had turned it down. It was later said it was down to the government's dealing with science funding and cuts. Paul Weller The musician rejected his CBE in 2006. In a statement his spokesperson said: “Paul was surprised and flattered, but it wasn’t really for him.” Lynn Faulds Wood In 2016, former BBC watchdog presenter Lynn Faulds Wood turned down an MBE and suggested that the honours system needs updating to reflect the modern world. She said: “I would love an honour if it didn’t have the word ‘empire’ at the end of it. We don’t have an empire.” John Cleese  The Monty Python star was offered a CBE in 1996 but said they were silly. He was offered a peerage by Lib Dem leader Paddy Ashdown in 1999 - he declined because he felt staying in England during the winter months to fulfil his role as a working peer was too much of a price to pay. George Harrison The former Beatle turned an OBE down in 2000 - after Paul McCartnery was awarded a knighthood. Every Beatles member was awarded an MBE in 1965, though Lennon returned him. It's thought he was put forward for his contribution to music, but there was speculation that Harrison would have been insulted that McCartney got his knighthood three years before. “Whoever it was who decided to offer him the OBE and not the knighthood was extraordinarily insensitive,” friend Roy Connolly told the Independent. “George would have felt insulted – and with very good reason.” Ken Loach Ken Loach turned down an OBE in 1977. His films focus on social issues such as poverty and homlessness. He told the Radio Times in 2001. “It’s all the things I think are despicable: patronage, deferring to the monarchy and the name of the British Empire, which is a monument of exploitation and conquest. “I turned down the OBE because it’s not a club you want to join when you look at the villains who’ve got it.” Howard Gayle  Howard Gayle, Liverpool FC’s first black player, also turned down an MBE, saying it would be a 'betrayal’ of Africans who suffered as a result of the empire and that his “ancestors would be turning in their graves.” He was nominated for his work with Show Racism the Red Card. Taking to Facebook he said: “This is a decision that I have had to make and there will be others who may feel different and would enjoy the attraction of being a Member of the British Empire and those 3 letters after their name, but I feel that It would be a betrayal to all of the Africans who have lost their lives, or who have suffered as a result of Empire.” Jon Snow  Having declined an OBE in 2000, Channel 4 News presenter Jon Snow went on to make a documentary in 2002 entitled ‘Secrets of the Honours System’. He remains critical of the use of ‘Empire’ in our honours system. “I tried to find out why I’d been given it and was unable to get a clear answer or, indeed, to find out who had proposed me, he said afterwards. Alan Bennett Alan turned down the offer of a CBE in 1988 and rejected a knighthood in 1996. The author and playwright said the reason was he couldn't carry off being a knight. “I felt that, in my case, it just wouldn’t suit me, that’s all. It would be like wearing a suit every day of your life.” Jim Broadbent Jim Broadbent was offered an OBE but he turned it down as he felt it should go to those who help others. In 2012 he said: “I was offered an OBE a couple of years ago, but I said, ‘no’, and turned it down.” “I’m not that comfortable with actors receiving honours, partly because I think they ought to go to those who really help others, he told the . “Besides, I like the idea of actors not being part of the Establishment. “We’re vagabonds and rogues, and we’re not a part of the authorities and Establishment, really. If you mix the two together, things get blurry.” LS Lowry  Lowry declined five honours – an OBE in 1955, CBE in 61, knighthood in 68 and invitations to be a Companion of Honour in 1972 and 76. Friend and fellow artist Harold Riley said when the list was revealed in 2012 that the painter did not have “anything against the system”. He said: “He indicated he didn’t wish to change his situation by something being latched on to him.” Riley said Lowry was a “very private person” and may have wanted to protect his privacy. Danny Boyle Danny Boyle, director and man behind the London 2012 Olympics opening ceremony, turned down an honour because he thought it was was wrong. It's just not me, he said. He added thousands were involved in executing the ceremony. “You can make these speeches about ‘this is everybody’s work, blah blah blah’, he said. “And you’ve got to mean it, and I did mean it, and it is true, and it’s the only way you can carry on something like that: through the efforts of all the people. “I don’t know whether I’ll ever get invited back to the Palace.” Aldous Huxley Aldous Huxley, author of classic novel Brave New World, snubbed a knighthood in 1959. Evelyn Waugh Evelyn Waugh, who wrote Brideshead Revisited among other famous titles, refused a CBE in the same year. Roald Dahl  Charlie and the Chocolate Factory author Roald Dahl rejected an OBE in the 1986 New Year’s Honours. Trevor Howard The actor Trevor Howard, star of romance Brief Encounter, would not accept a CBE in 1982. In 1979 the Labour Prime Minister Jim Callaghan’s wife Audrey refused to be made a Dame. It was the year Mr Callaghan led Labour to defeat against Margaret Thatcher’s Tories. However, Mrs Callaghan later acquired a title when her husband became a peer in 1987. Hughie Green The Opportunity Knocks star Hughie Green refused an OBE in the 1960 New Year’s Honours, when he was at the height of his fame as presenter of Double Your Money. Michael Frayn Author and playwright Michael Frayn turned down a knighthood in 2003, and a CBE in 1999, for a simple reason. He said: “I haven’t done this for reasons of modesty. I like the name Michael Frayn it’s a nice little name to run around with. I’ve spent 70 years getting used to it and I don’t want to change it now.” Ian McDiarmid Ian, known for playing Palpatine in Star Wars, turned down an OBE, but it's not know why. Prime Ministers  Former Prime Ministers Sir John Major, Tony Blair and Gordon Brown have all declined life peerages. Sir Winston Churchill reportedly declined being created Duke of London because he wished to remain in the House of Commons. Stars who refused an award - but later accepted them  Psycho and The Birds director Hitchcock turned down a CBE in 1962, but accepted a knighthood just before he died. Sculptor Henry Moore, the son of a coal miner, refused a knighthood in 1951, but became a Companion of Honour in 1955. Conversely actor Robert Morley, who accepted an OBE in 1957, rejected a knighthood in the 1975 Birthday Honours list. And Hugh Cudlipp, who edited The Daily Mirror in the 50s and 60s turned down a knighthood in 1966, although he had accepted an OBE in 1945. Artist Lucian Freud declined a CBE in 1977 but went to Downing Street to paint the Queen’s portrait.  Poet Philip Larkin refused an OBE in 1968. Nobel Prize winner Francis Crick turned down a CBE in 1963, before accepting the Order of Merit in 1991. Lenny Henry accepted a CBE from Tony Blair but refused an honour from John Major. story: NewsBoy, six, plays with an inflatable alligator in his garden... while a REAL one hides just behind himThe footage was captured by Timmy's mum Nicole Majica who filmed her son as he played in the back yard of their home in Orlando, Florida&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByElaine McCahill09:30, 8 JUN 2018Updated10:13, 8 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThis is the moment a young boy plays with an inflatable alligator - as a real one hides just behind him. Incredible footage shows Timmy, six, playing with the bright green slip and slide in the garden of his home in Orlando, Florida. as the animal lurks just feet away. His mum Nicole Mojica was filming Timmy in the sunshine and didn't realise how close the creature had come to her son she watched the clip back afterwards. story: NewsChildren found sweating and crying locked inside mum's car as temperatures hit sweltering 36 degreesAndrea Nelson said something didn't feel quite right when she was pulled into the car park at a shopping centre&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByKelly-Ann Mills00:02, 8 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA concerned woman who spotted two young children sweating and crying in a car called police as temperatures soared to 36 degrees Celcius.
