title: mother sentenced life boyfriend gets
story: NewsMother sentenced to life and boyfriend gets death penalty after torturing son, 8, to death because they though he may be gayPearl Fernandez, 34, and her boyfriend Isauro Aguirre, 37, whipped, beat and tortured little Gabriel Fernandez in a catalogue of horrific attacks&nbspShareByElaine McCahill10:51, 8 JUN 2018NewsGabriel Fernandez, 8, was tortured to death by his mother Pearl Fernandez and her boyfriend Isauro Aguirre (Image: KTLA)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mother has been sentenced to life in prison for torturing her eight-year-old son to death because she thought he might be gay. Pearl Fernandez, 34, was sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole while her boyfriend Isauro Aguirre, 37, was sentenced to death for the death of her son Gabriel.  The pair bit, whipped and beat little Gabriel Fernandez in catalogue of horrific attacks at their home in Palmdale, California.  In the months leading up to his death, Gabriel was covered with pepper spray, forced to eat his own vomit, regularly gagged to stop him from speaking and locked in a cabinet when he complained, the court heard.  Fernandez and Isauro also burned him with cigarettes, whipped him, shot him with a BB gun, starved him and fed him cat litter. The boy was kept gagged and bound in a cubby until he was found, a Los Angeles County District Attorney's Office heard. Before reading their sentences, Judge George G. Lomeli said their conduct was horrendous, inhumane and nothing short of evil.  You want to say that the conduct was animalistic, but that would be wrong because even animals know how to take care of their young, some to the extent that they would sacrifice their own lives in caring for their young, Lomeli said as he stared directly toward Fernandez and Aguirre in the court room, reports ABC .  He then told a touching story of a news report he once watched about a mother cat who kept going into burning building to save her kittens.  Judge Lomeli continued: I can only wish...that in the middle of the night you wake up, and you think of the injuries that you subjected on this poor young man, this poor 7-year-old, and that it tortures you. Last December, the jury recommended that Aguirre be sentence to death after he was convicted of first-degree murder and the special circumstance allegation of murder involving torture. In February, Fernandez pleaded guilty to first-degree murder and admitted to the torture special circumstance allegation in order to get life in prison without parole. If the case had gone to trial and she had been convicted as charged, she would have also been facing the death penalty.  At her sentencing hearing, Fernandez read an apology letter out loud, saying she hopes one day her children can forgive her.   I want to say I'm sorry for what happened. I wish Gabriel was alive. Every day I wish that I'd made better choices. I'm sorry to my children, and I want them to know that I love them, she said.   Gabriel's brother Ezequiel, who was 12 at the time and is now aged 16, and sister Virginia, who was 11 at the time and is now aged 14, gave heartbreaking evidence last year. Ezequiel said Aguirre would punch and kick the boy and pick him up by the neck until he passed out. The court went silent as a cabinet recovered from the home was rolled in. Ezequiel said the couple nicknamed it 'the box' and would handcuff Gabriel inside for hours on end without food or water. He also saw Aguirre beat Gabriel with a buckle and metal hanger while he was naked. He said his mum and Aguirre would often laugh as they beat the boy together, calling him gay.

title: researchers offer pay volunteers 2600
story: NewsResearchers offer to pay volunteers £2600 to expose themselves to flu at 'Hotel Influenza' in universal vaccine bidThey would be quarantined for 10 days and deliberately allow their bodies to be challenged to see if they get sick&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDanya BazaraaNews Reporter14:40, 8 JUN 2018NewsVolunteers would stay at Hotel Influenza (Image: Courtesy of SLU's Center for Vaccine Development)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailResearchers are asking for volunteers who will intentionally expose themselves to flu in a desperate bid to find a universal vaccine. The guinea pigs will be paid about $3,500 (&pound2619.72) for deliberately allowing their bodies to be challenged to see if they get ill.  And they would be quarantined for 10 days in 'Hotel Influenza,' a converted 24-room suite at Saint Louis University, Missouri, US.  Communal areas in the accommodation have comfortable sofas and spaces to socialise, watch TV and read, and exercise equipment is available. The experience is also catered with meals offered in the dining room.   Daniel Hoft, director of SLU’s Center for Vaccine Development, said: The Extended Stay Research Unit will allow SLU to take its vaccine research to the next level. SLU has invested in this because it is an important way to potentially contribute significantly to the development of a universal flu vaccine, he added.  Human challenge studies are a way to get a lot of information quicker, with a smaller number of volunteers and less cost than a traditional vaccine study. In a traditional flu study, we vaccinate people and see if their immune systems respond by creating antibodies that fight flu.  In a human challenge study, we vaccinate people, then deliberately challenge their bodies by exposing them to flu to see if they get sick.”  Volunteers as part of this challenge would be given a vaccine or placebo, then intentionally exposed to a strain of the influenza virus. In the 10 days that follow, they are observed closely with blood and lung tests and nose swabs to see if they are infected with the virus and shedding it through bodily secretions.  Nurses are on hand constantly to care for them. And participants are not allowed to go home until show they are negative for infection for two days. The reason they're quarantined is because it takes time for symptoms to develop and the contagious period to be over.  There is a 'clean room' in the 'hotel' with work spaces for non-volunteers who come and go into the unit.

Countries where sex toys are banned  1. They come under the heading of pornographic material which is completely banned by the Maldives Customs Service.  2. Malaysia The Malaysian Penal Code states that anyone who sells, distributes or possesses an obscene book, pamphlet, paper, drawing, painting, representation or figure, or any other obscene object whatsover... shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both. 4. story: NewsWhen is Father's Day 2018? UK and worldwide dates and why we celebrate it and how it all beganWhat is the meaning behind Father's Day 2018 and what are the best gifts and cards to buy dad? All your questions answered&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByEmma MunbodhPersonal Finance CorrespondentJo-Anne RowneyAudience Growth Editor09:45, 4 JUN 2018Updated12:06, 6 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt's not long until Father's Day - it falls on Sunday, June 17. The average dad in Britain spends four hours a week as a taxi driver, 27 days a year on DIY duties and if you put a price on the number of spiders he's cleared for you - it'd be &pound10,000. With Father’s Day approaching in the UK, online gift retailer Getting Personal has uncovered the true cost of fatherhood - and if it came with a salary, it would be &pound67,000 per year. If you're thinking of getting him something a little different this year - or just fancy celebrating the big day in style - see our list of top Father's Day experiences here.  When is Fathers Day 2018? Mother's Day might feel like it's only just over, but Father's Day will be here before we know it. It is usually held on the third Sunday of June. This year, it falls on Sunday June 17. Unlike Mother's Day, the USA and the UK celebrate Father's Day on the same day. This is the most common day to celebrate Father's Day, with France, Canada, South Africa, Greece, China, Netherlands, Mexico, Nigeria, Pakistan and many others marking the day.  What about the rest of the world? In similar style to Mother's Day , Father's Day does vary in date around the world. Here are the dates for your diary if you're abroad:  Russia: February 23 (Defender of the Fatherland Day) Andorra, Bolivia, Honduras, Italy, Portugal, Spain: March 19 Germany: Ascension Day - May 10 in 2018 Lithuania, Switzerland: First Sunday in June Denmark: June 5 Austria, Belgium: Second Sunday in June Egypt, Jordan, Lebanon: 21 June El Salvador, Guatemala: 17 June Poland, Nicaragua: 23 June Haiti: Last Sunday in June Uruguay: Second Sunday in July   Dominican Republic: Last Sunday in July   Brazil, Samoa: Second Sunday in August Australia, Fiji, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea: First Sunday in September Latvia: Second Sunday in September Luxembourg: First Sunday in October Estonia, Finland, Iceland, Norway and Sweden: Second Sunday in November  How is Father's Day traditionally celebrated?  Following in the footsteps of Valentine's Day which celebrates your loved one and Mother's Day to show the woman in your life just how special she is, Father's Day is a worldwide occasion in celebration of your dad. Falling on the third Sunday in June, it celebrates the impact fathers and father figures have on the lives of their children. Although it is celebrated on a variety of dates worldwide, it's an internationally recognised event. Father's Day began around 100 years ago over in the US and has since made its mark all over the world. Best Father's Day gift ideas for 2018: From budget presents under &pound30 to top luxury and personalised gifts How did Father's Day begin? The exact origin has been disputed. Most believe it began with Sonora Dodd, from Washington, who came up with the idea after hearing the Mother's Day sermon in 1910 and thinking (not without good reason) why the dads didn't have their own day too. She and her siblings had been raised by their father after their mum died in childbirth. Dodd began a campaign...and well, the rest is history. Other people argue it was Grace Golden Clayton from West Virginia, who suggested celebrating the day in 1908. She apparently put the suggestion forward after a mine explosion in a nearby town killed more than 360 men - the idea being it was a day for children to remember their fathers. Whatever the reason, we're glad of it.  How is it celebrated around the world? We know what the traditions are in the UK, but what about abroad? In Germany it's called Vatertag or Mannertag (or men's day). It's traditional in some places for men to go into the woods with a wagon of beer, wine and meats. In China it's marked on the 8th August because eight in Chinese is 'ba' and a colloquial way of saying father is 'ba-ba' - so eighth day of the eighth month sounds like father. title: multi tasking dad three comforts
story: NewsMulti-tasking dad-of-three comforts stage-fraught daughter by performing ballet routine by her sideDad Marc Daniels from Bermuda comforted his daughter during her ballet recital by performing the routine by her side&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByMiranda Blazeby12:15, 8 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThis dad proved that men can indeed multi-task after he jumped to comfort his nervous daughter by performing an entire ballet routine by her side - all while holding his baby in his arms. Self-employed barrister and dad-of-three Marc Daniels already has his work cut out balancing his home life with busy work commitments. But he outdid himself on May 29 by jumping to his daughter Bella's aid when she was overcome by stage fright. An audience member captured the heartwarming moment during the dress rehearsal of Bella's first ballet recital in Hamilton, Bermuda.  As the children shuffle onstage, it becomes clear all is not well with two-and-a-half-year old Bella who begins to cry as stage fright takes hold. As her tantrum begins to throw a spanner in the works, Marc is summoned onstage by teachers to help calm her down. But Marc goes one better as he appears onstage to cheers of the audience. Clutching his youngest daughter Suri, he holds Bella's hand as he plies, spins and points his toes alongside his daughter.

title: two boozed up men caught
story: NewsTwo boozed-up men caught on CCTV dragging away the body of their friend who died during vodka drinking sessionThe men decided to hide the body over fears they would be blamed for their pal's death&nbspShareByElaine McCahill14:32, 8 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCCTV cameras captured two boozed-up men dragging away the body of their friend who dropped dead during a vodka drinking spree. The incident happened in the city of Saratov in Russia's south-western Saratov Oblast region. The images show two men, looking furtively around them as they drag their pal's body along the street in a carpet. According to local media, the trio started their drinking session in the morning and continued until late that night. One of the men reportedly began to feel ill from the enormous amount of vodka and passed out. He died shortly afterwards.  Reports said his buddies were stunned by his sudden death and after drinking a bit more, they decided to get rid of the body out of fear they might be accused of his death. They wrapped their friend's body in a carpet and carried it to the next block of flats before leaving it outside on the ground. However, they failed to notice the CCTV camera mounted in the entrance to their block of flats.

title: dog walkers and campers may have seen flasher who left woman shaken
story: Police are appealing for witnesses following a public indecency.The incident happened around 8.45pm on Thursday 7th June on the Fife Coastal Path, near to St Bridget&#8217s Kirk in Dalgety Bay, Fife.A 51-year-old woman was walking in the area when a man approached and exposed himself to her before making off from the area.Inquiries are ongoing to trace the suspect and anyone who can assist officers with their investigation is asked to come forward.He is described as white, between 35 and 40-years-old, average height, short cropped hair and was wearing a black vest and dark tracksuit bottoms with a red stripe down the leg.Sergeant Kenny Bow from Dalgety Bay Police Station said: “The victim was left shaken by this incident and we are pursuing local lines of inquiry to identify the suspect.&#8220The area is very popular with dog walkers and a number of young people are believed to have been camping out in the area on Thursday night, so I would ask anyone who may have seen this male to come forward,“We will have additional patrols in place along the local Coastal Path to speak with potential witnesses, offer reassurance to the local community and gather any evidence that can help identify the culprit.&#8220If you believe you have any information relevant to our inquiries then please contact police immediately.&#8221Those with information can contact Dalgety Bay Police Station via 101 and quote incident 4145 of the 7th June of the 7th June. Alternatively, an anonymous report can be made to the charity Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111.

title: dundee family gets together to honour special womans 106th birthday
story: When you think of the year 1912 it seems like a completely different world.But in that year Ethel Lees was born in the small village of Newtyle – and just a few weeks ago, on May 23, she celebrated her 106th birthday with her large family.Ethel was raised in a two-bedroom flat in Lorimer Street, Dundee, and later in Roseangle House as one of eight girls and four boys in the Milne family.At the age of 23, Ethel married husband John at the registrar’s office which was located at the bottom of King Street.The couple had three children together Brian, Jack and Muriel.In 1963 the couple, together with son Brian, moved to Toronto, Canada, where daughter Muriel lived, and they were joined by son Jack two years later.Tragically the family were only there for four years before Ethel’s husband died at the age of 55.Ethel stayed in Canada with her daughter until 2013 when Muriel died following a lengthy illness.Although Ethel often visited Dundee she only moved back permanently to Broughty Ferry in February, where she now lives with son Brian.Although Ethel’s hearing is starting to deteriorate at the grand age of 106, she has had no major operations and her memory is second to none as she often reflects on her time playing field hockey as a goalie or her time spent travelling the world competing in Scottish Dancing competitions.She learned to drive while in Canada and only stopped when she was 92.Ethel said: “I have been very lucky to live this long and it is great to still keep in touch with my sister Ruby who will be 99 this year.“I have a great memory and could tell you stories and memories for days.”Her sons Brian and Jack said: “With a thousand stories and memories all the family wish this remarkable woman a very happy birthday and we hope she enjoyed her special day.”

title: dundee man told ex he would ensure intimate pics of her go viral
story: A man who admitted sending abusive and threatening text messages to his ex-partner and her grandmother has been spared jail.Steven Tosh, 26, of Maitland Street, had sentence deferred last month, having previously admitted sending the messages to Amber Kenyon and Frances McVicar.Dundee Sheriff Court heard that Tosh and Ms Kenyon had been in a relationship since August 2017, but that had finished around the end of November last year.At 8.30pm on January 15, Ms Kenyon received a text from Tosh in which he implied she had started a relationship with another man.Another text read: “Always knew you for what you are.”In another, he implied he would let intimate photographs of Ms Kenyon “go viral” – although the court was told that in fact the images did not exist. Ms Kenyon, who was living with her grandmother at the time, subsequently blocked Tosh’s number.The court was told Ms McVicar received an abusive video message from Tosh on January 19, described as “rambling.”Both women were upset by this, and contacted police.The court heard the messages had been intended to be “a joke”, but Tosh “appreciated this was not how it came across”.He admitted that on various occasions between January 15 and 19, he sent grossly offensive text messages to Ms Kenyon which were indecent, obscene or menacing in character in that he repeatedly referred to her in offensive and abusive terms and threatened to expose intimate photographs of her.He further admitted that he sent text and video messages to Ms McVicar that were grossly offensive or indecent, obscene or menacing in character, shouted, swore and used offensive and abusive language.Sheriff John Rafferty said: “You have two recently analogous matters on your record in 2012 and 2013.“You have also breached bail opportunities on six occasions. I’m prepared to give you the chance of a community-based disposal. If you breach that then you will go to jail.”A restriction of liberty order was put in place, requiring Tosh to be in his house from 7pm-6am for four months.

title: dundee people bookshop managers book tour to the outer hebrides
story: A bookshop manager is setting off on a 275-mile journey to the Outer Hebrides, armed with more than 600 books for school children.Robin Crawford, from Waterstone’s in Commercial Street, will travel to Benbecula in the Western Isles as the bookseller brings a two day pop-up bookshop to Lionacleit School, as part of the First Minister’s Reading Challenge.The school is the only secondary school serving Benbecula and North and South Uist and access to books is limited.The bookshop will be open to pupils, parents and the wider community, offering a selection of books in English and Gaelic.Robin said: “I am delighted to be making this journey to create a bookshop experience for book lovers on Benbecula.”

title: dundee people frankensteins links to dundee in monster new edition
story: Frankenstein author Mary Shelley’s links to the city will be celebrated by a new Dundee edition of her “monster” story, which is to be published and distributed free to local children later in the year.Frankenstein: Or, The Modern Prometheus will be released online in a downloadable format, while thousands of hard copies will also be printed.Edited and introduced by Dr Daniel Cook, of Dundee University’s English department, the book will comprise the complete 1818 text of the ground-breaking science fiction novel, as well as dozens of commissioned images produced by award-winning local comics artists.“Frankenstein is one of the most influential novels ever written,” said Dr Cook. “It is studied in schools and universities across the English-speaking world, and everyone is in some way familiar with the story of the god-like scientist and his monstrous creation.”Shelley spent two years living on South Baffin Street as a teenager, from 1812-14, after her father, William Godwin, sent her to live with the wealthy jute-producing Baxter family.This spell would influence her, as she acknowledged: “It was beneath the trees of the grounds belonging to our house, or on the bleak sides of the woodless mountains near, that my true compositions, the airy flights of my imagination, were born and fostered.”The project is funded by the Art and Humanities Research Institute.

title: dundee people friends raise cash for cuddle cot in memory of aalayah
story: A group has raised £500 with a sponsored walk over the Tay Road Bridge in memory of baby Aalayah’s fundraiser .The daughter of Kayleigh and Darren Smith spent 19 weeks at home before she sadly died last October.Her parents were able to keep her at home for the 10 days leading up to her funeral thanks to a cuddle cot they were given.The couple have since been fundraising in an effort to raise money for a new cuddle cot to be donated to the hospital.Kayleigh said: “We have now reached our target to purchase one cuddle cot and we are currently raising funds towards buying a second one in memory of Aalayah.“Our last fundraising event is a disco on Saturday at Fairfield Sport and Social Club.”Anyone wishing to purchase tickets for the disco can find information on Aalayah’s fundraiser page on Facebook.

title: dundee people from a childhood in the opera to running a music studio tristans life in music
story: The genre may have changed but the music Tristan Button grew up surrounded by still has an effect on him.The 37-year-old, who realised his dream of running a studio nine years ago when he launched Dundee Music Studios, said his father was president of the Tayside Opera for many years.&#8220There was constantly people coming around the house, other people from the opera would all come around, drink some wine and sing some songs,&#8221 he said.&#8220It was mainly classical music that I was interested in when I was very very young.&#8220If there was ever any children&#8217s parts, me and my sister would get dressed up and thrown on stage, I sure to enjoy that.&#8220There was never much singing involved, it was mostly just being children running around on stage.&#8221Tristan said he started playing the cornet when he was four or five, and then moved on to the baritone horn while he was a student at Grange Primary School in Monifieth.&#8220But I always wanted to play the trombone and they didn&#8217t have one in the music department, but eventually the must have got a bit of extra cash and got a trombone so I started playing the trombone,&#8221 he said.&#8220And I did that right thought to near the end of high school.&#8221While he trained and began working as an engineer, he started DJing electronic and hip-hop music, later moving into scratch DJing.&#8220Some of my friends had a band and my best friend had just been asked to be the drummer so he asked if I wanted to come along and do some scratching on top of the music,&#8221 he said.After a few weeks, Tristan asked if they were ok with him bringing along his synthesizers and the band kicked off from there.&#8220It was great, we had a great time doing that and the band was together for about 12 years.&#8221Spending most of his spare time being involved in music and going into so many studios, Tristan said he always had it in the back of his mind that he one day wanted to run his one of his own.He took a few business classes and looked into what it would involve, but the timing didn&#8217t feel quite right.Then in 2007, both his parents passed away within two months of each other.&#8220It kind of just turned my life on it&#8217s head,&#8221 he said.He quit his job and spent six months travelling around Australia with his future wife, before coming back to DundeeThen in 2009 he was told that a charity studio run by his friend&#8217s dad near the Marketgait was up for sale, and Tristan decided to take the chance.&#8220It was quite a big thing for me, a bit of a massive thing for me actually but at that point in my life it was a risk I was willing to take,&#8221 he said.He launched the studio, a band booked one of his rooms full time and the business began to slowly grow, but it wasn&#8217t until about a year and a half after opening that it began to turn profitable.&#8220I remember six months into it being really really worried about things, that I might not be able to keep running,&#8221 he said.&#8220But I persevered with it and it&#8217s worked out.&#8220I&#8217m never going to be a millionaire from running the studio but it&#8217s more of a lifestyle job. I get to spend an awful lot of time with my kids which I&#8217m quite grateful for.&#8221There is still a lot of hard work which goes into the studio, with Tristan and Harris, one of the studio&#8217s staff, staying up until 5am one recent weekend to prepare it for the launch of the Dundee Music Academy, but it&#8217s paying off.The Academy is Tristan&#8217s next big project and he wants to encourage more people to start playing music.&#8220We&#8217ve got big plans for the music academy and high hopes for it,&#8221 he said.

title: dundee people pictures dundee youngsters take steps to show off their urban moves
story: Hundreds of little groovers had the chance to show their moves in the city’s biggest dance festival.The festival, which took place at the Gardyne Theatre, saw approximately 600 children showing off what they have learned in their Urban Moves dance classes run by Leisure and Culture Dundee.Running over three days, the dance festival invited different Urban Moves classes to show off their skills to friends, family and other dance enthusiasts, ensuring all of the varying age groups got the opportunity to experience dancing on the big stage.“We have also now extended to evening classes for some of the more senior pupils from S1 upwards.“At the event all the kids were great – with so many children it could have been crazy but they were all fantastic and so keen to get up on the stage.“We work with them all year round to build up their confidence so there was no stage fright. They were all raring to go.”Alongside primary school groups, there was also the chance for the dance programme’s elite dancers from the Urban Moves Junior Company, Urban Moves Training Company and Urban Moves Dance Company to showcase their skills.Alex added: “It was great having the development companies perform each night too.“I think it definitely gave the younger children some inspiration on what they can do and they just loved sharing the stage with them.”The Dance Company was also recently involved in a promotional video for Maggie’s Penguin Parade, which kicks off this summer, and will be heavily involved with shows throughout the next few months.Alex Hare, dance manager for Leisure and Culture Dundee, said the three day event was “absolutely fantastic”.She said: “The weekend was full of incredible dancing and each and every dancer and member of the audience had an amazing time.“The weekend showcase is an annual event and really gives the kids a chance to show the skills they have learned throughout the year in their dance classes.“In partnership with Dundee City Council, Urban Moves goes into primary schools each week after school and teaches the kids new routines and help them develop new skills.The Claypotts Castle PS (P1-3) Urban Moves Junior Group.

title: dundee people trying to find after 73 years mervyns looking for family ties to dundee
story: An adopted man whose mother went into labour while in prison has appealed for information in Tayside as he now believes he has family ties to Dundee.Mervyn Miller, 73, was put up for adoption after he was born three months premature while his unmarried mother was in HM Prison Edinburgh, having been locked up in 1944 for shoplifting.Mervyn said he has lived a “lucky” life but, upon retirement, decided to trace his family history. He has uncovered ties to Dundee and is appealing to anyone who may have known his mother, whose birth certificate he has not found.He believes his mum, Irene Miller or Millar, was born in Canada but grew up and worked in Dundee. Mervyn thinks his maternal grandmother travelled to Canada while pregnant, but returned to Scotland shortly afterwards.He has found a cousin, Freda, and an uncle, Raymond, who live in Dundee, but neither has been able to shed much light on the mystery. Freda’s mum also lived in Dundee and Mervyn suspects she and his mum would have hung about together.He said: “It would be a great satisfaction to know what happened to her. We just can’t find a birth certificate. In a jute mill or other factory, everyone knows everyone so there might be someone in Dundee who knew my mother.”Irene ended up in Liverpool working as a prostitute but that is where the trail goes cold.His father is even more of a mystery, but as Mervyn is mixed-race he believes a man from Pakistan, India or Sri Lanka came to Dundee for the jute industry.Born with spina bifida, Mervyn spent much of his childhood at a children’s centre in Edinburgh. Aged 18, he needed both feet amputated after a series of ulcers and fevers.

title: dundee street closed after man run over in collision involving bmw and vauxhall
story: A Dundee street is closed &#8220until further notice&#8221 after a traffic accident this afternoon.Emergency services are currently in attendance after a road traffic collision at the junction of Dudhope Terrace and Lochee Road, which happened at 1pm today.It is thought that a man was &#8220run over&#8221 in a collision involving a red BMW and Vauxhall left a man &#8220run over&#8221. One of the vehicles is believed to have attempted to avoid the pedestrian before running him over and colliding with the other vehicle.A witness told the Tele that a &#8220number of bystanders&#8221 ran over to help the injured man, believed to be in his 40s.They added that an ambulance was first on the scene, followed by two fire units, a police van and two police cars.A police spokesman said: &#8220A pedestrian has suffered leg injuries following a collision with a car. His injuries are not thought to be life threatening.&#8220Dudhope Terrace is currently closed until further notice.&#8221&nbsp

title: dundee united invest 20000 so tannadice continues to be one of the best surfaces in the country
story: Dundee United are investing over £20,000 this summer to make sure they have the best playing surface in the Championship.Since manager Csaba Laszlo was appointed in November, he’s stressed the need for a pristine pitch to match the passing style he wants from the Tangerines.And while last season the surface was the envy of most of their second-tier rivals, the board have stumped up five figures to make sure it’s even better next term and beyond.They announced this week the existing turf has been lifted and a process known as vertical sand-banding started.While that’s a complicated, as well as expensive, process, the new and improved pitch will be ready when the first of the Betfred Cup group matches kick off there in as little as six weeks.The work being carried out will also improve drainage – something that has been a problem, particularly in the area near the tunnel at the Eddie Thompson Stand end of Tannadice.And, while most of the budget for the next 12 months is going on putting together a squad capable of winning promotion, chairman Mike Martin is viewing the pitch project as a sound investment.“We are investing in our on and off-field operations in a structured way with every aspect of our work designed to deliver improvement throughout the club,” he said.“In this case, we aim to make sure that Tannadice continues to be one of the best surfaces in the country for playing professional football.”Those Betfred Cup fixtures are expected to be confirmed next week with league fixtures out on June 14.

title: dundee united step up keeper search as mehmet begins recovery from knee injury
story: Dundee United have stepped up their search for a new goalkeeper as Deniz Mehmet begins his recovery from a knee injury.The London-born Turkish youth international injured himself in the aftermath of Scott McDonald’s play-off equaliser against Dunfermline on May 4.A month on and Deniz has finally going under the knife to sort the problem after swelling delayed the operation.The 25-year-old had travelled to London for the op last week only to be told he would have to wait a bit longer.That wait is over as he underwent surgery yesterday to begin the long road to recovery.Deniz tweeted today to say the operation &#8220went well&#8221 and hopes to be &#8220back not long after the start of the season ahead&#8221.&mdash Deniz Doğan Mehmet (@Deniz_Mehmet1) June 6, 2018His recovery is expected to take some time and United don’t plan to have him available for the first few months of the season.With only 18-year-old goalie Josh Donaldson on the books, the Tangerines are on the look-out for a new man between the sticks, even if just for the first half of the campaign.Aberdeen’s Danny Rogers has already been named as a possible incomer on loan to fill the gap.The New York-born Irish U/21 international has spent three seasons on loan in the Championship with Dumbarton and Falkirk and knows the division.&nbsp

title: dundee united takeover no news is good news
story: Dundee United associate director Stuart Campbell, who represents fans’ group ArabTRUST on the club board, insists no news over the potential takeover at Tannadice is good news.In a blog post he said: “Since Mike Martin was appointed chairman we’ve seen the implementation of the widely reported ‘root &amp branch’ review of everything that happens at the club.“While we expect to see many more changes reported over the next few months, changes have already been made in finance, recruitment, youth and commercial.“The chairman, directors and staff at Tannadice have been putting in long hours to bring about the changes needed that will give the club the best chance of delivering the promotion to the Premiership and the financial stability we all want.“I’m not evading the ‘elephant in the room’ but really can’t answer any of the questions many of us have on the reported potential takeover/ investment in the club.“ArabTRUST are taking the view at this stage that a lack of information is a positive sign that any negotiations are taking place in a business-like manner and when it’s possible the club will bring us all up to date with any developments.“Too many times in the past we’ve seen gossip drip fed into the media on all sorts of issues where ultimately everyone has been left frustrated and disappointed.“We must also remember any discussions of this nature will be private discussions between shareholders and potential other parties.”

title: ex dundee man etxabeguren one of two new defensive targets for dundee united
story: Dundee United’s search for new centre-backs continues apace as former Dundee defender Julen Etxabeguren and ex-Tannadice man Callum Morris have been added to their list of targets.Both are free agents, though, the Tangerines face a battle to land either signature.Etxabeguren was released by the Dark Blues last month after an injury-hit year and has returned to Spain.Whether he can be enticed back to Scotland remains to be seen, although, he did enjoy his time in Dundee.Morris, meanwhile, told Dunfermline he was leaving them to return to England but a move back to former club United might be enough for him to shelve those plans.The 28-year-old played 45 times for Jackie McNamara at Tannadice over two seasons but, like Etxabeguren, has a history of injuries.He did play 40 games last season for the Pars, however.Also on the list is former Partick man Frederic Frans.The Belgian centre-back is wanted by his former club also, as well as fellow-Championship side Ross County.Meanwhile, United have announced their first pre-season friendly.Csaba Laszlo’s men will head to Brechin City on Tuesday, July 3, kick-off 7.45pm.That sees both city clubs heading to Glebe Park in pre-season because it’s the only grass pitch in the area, apart from Arbroath.n Former Dundee United favourite Nadir Ciftci is leaving Celtic at the end of this month.Motherwell are favourites to sign the man they had on loan last season.

title: manchester united boss jose mourinho watches dundees former arsenal midfielder glen kamara amid transfer speculation
story: Jose Mourinho was watching as Dundee’s Glen Kamara picked up his fourth international cap in Finland’s friendly defeat in Romania.The 22-year-old has drawn plenty of interest in his time at the Dark Blues – Mourinho, however, was only there as a guest of Romanian agent Ioan Becali and stressed in an ad-hoc TV interview he wasn’t looking at players, just enjoying his time off.Kamara, meanwhile, despite only joining up with the Finnish national squad on Monday, played the majority of the second half in Ploiesti.The Finns, ranked 62nd in the world and not at this year’s World Cup, started the friendly match well but fell behind in the first half to Cristean Manea’s 37th-minute strike.In the second period, Kamara made his entrance after 57 minutes for Nottingham Forest’s Thomas Lam but almost immediately the team fell further behind.On 61 minutes, winger Ciprian Deac finished from close range to give the Romanians a home victory.Finland boss Markku Kanerva said: “The start was challenging but we looked good. We fought well and did not give up.“Of course, we should not be satisfied with this result but we did not have a full squad.“At the end, we got a little bit to attack more.“I had to think a little about the team when Pyry Soiri and Glen Kamara were only involved on Monday for the first time so they only played the second period.“There was little to be done in the last third. Romania defended the centre very well and, of course, it is a good team.”Finland play Belarus in Kamara’s birthplace, Tampere, on Saturday.

title: over to you dundee council set to ask procurator fiscal to consider charging jute owners
story: The demolition of the B-listed Halley’s Mill in Dundee could be reported to the Procurator Fiscal.The mill on Broughty Ferry Road, also known as Wallace Craigie jute works, was knocked down on May 12 due to “safety concerns” under a warrant obtained under building standards.However, the process for tearing down listed buildings is different and therefore the proper permissions were not in place.A report to be considered by councillors recommends that Dundee City Council reports the demolition by the building’s owners under Section 8 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) (Scotland) Act 1997.Will Dawson, convener of Dundee City Council’s planning committee said: “As part of a verbal update to the last committee by the executive director of city development an undertaking was given to bring a report to the next planning committee“That report will be considered on Monday June 18 and it outlines the three options available to us – take no further action, issue an enforcement notice or report the matter to the Procurator Fiscal.“The executive director’s report recommends reporting the matter to the Procurator Fiscal and the committee will discuss the issue and reach its decision when it meets.”The committee will be told that on May 11 the city council became aware that demolition work had started on the former Wallace Craigie Works (Halley’s Mill) site, information that was confirmed when officers visited.Separate statutory permissions under planning and building legislation are needed from the council before any works, including demolition, can be carried out.Historic Environment Scotland has confirmed it was not asked to review the listing and was not contacted about the demolition proposal.It later advised that: “The demolition of Wallace Craigie Works has resulted in the complete loss of a Category B Listed Building, part of Dundee’s rich industrial heritage.”“It is now a matter for the council to decide what is in the public interest to happen next. We would fully expect this to be appropriate to the scale and seriousness of the unauthorised works undertaken.”In his report Mike Galloway, executive director of city development, lays out the arguments for and against the three possible options.The report notes that: “The unauthorised demolition of a Listed Building is a significant breach of National Legislation as reinforced through the comments by Historic Environment Scotland. Taking no further action is not considered to be an appropriate response”.Under consideration of serving an Enforcement Notice the report says it would not be an appropriate course of action because the building: “…has now been completely demolished and materials removed from the site”. Any restoration would not be reasonably practicable.When looking at whether to recommend reporting the matter to the Procurator Fiscal Mr Galloway’s report says: “There was frequent correspondence between council officers and the owner’s representatives late in 2017.“The information that was provided by the owner’s representatives, in the opinion of Dundee City Council engineers, clearly confirmed that while defects were present, demolition was not the only option to preserve safety or indeed the building.”It goes on: “Given the nature and the lack of notification or contact with Dundee City Council prior to the commencement of the demolition process, it is considered that this displays a disregard for the statutory process.”The report therefore recommends that Dundee City Council reports the matter to the Procurator Fiscal.

title: promising signs as csaba laszlo begins to create new dundee united
story: The summer of change at Tannadice has only just begun but the new-look Dundee United side is starting to take shape – what kind of shape are they in exactly, though?So far, the Tangerines have decimated last season’s pool with almost a full matchday squad list heading out the door.That left them with a skeleton squad before their business really got started last week.Five faces are in the door with the few players manager Csaba Laszlo wanted to keep given new contracts.More will be coming in during the next few weeks but, right now, how are they shaping up?GoalkeeperDeniz Mehmet looked certain to be the man between the sticks this season but for his knee injury picked up at the end of last season.With Harry Lewis heading back to Southampton after his loan, highly-rated youth keeper Josh Donaldson is the only fit goalie at the club.Verdict: A goalkeeper is certainly on the shopping list.DefenceTwo defenders have been brought in already this summer in Sam Wardrop and Callum Booth.Booth is expected to be first choice at left-back ahead of Jamie Robson while Wardrop will battle it out with Stewart Murdoch on the right.Though Murdoch has slotted in at centre-half, there is a big gap to be filled in that position.William Edjenguele, Tam Scobbie and Lewis Toshney are still around but Csaba and head scout Paul Sturrock are certainly looking for two starting centre-backs.Verdict: Big gap to fill in the middle but full-back positions look solid.MidfieldFit and healthy, Dundee United’s central midfield places are pretty much sewn up.Fraser Fyvie and Sam Stanton are the club’s stand-out talents at the moment and will occupy the middle of the park without doubt when available.In reserve is Scott Allardice after he signed a new one-year deal.Out wide, Fraser Aird has been brought in to play on the left side while Billy King is likely to start on the right.Paul McMullan hasn’t always been Csaba’s cup of tea but showed at the start of last season how effective he can be from the wings while youngster Matty Smith has slotted in out wide at times, though is nominally a striker.Verdict: Centre is strong when fit but numbers needed for a long season.AttackThe biggest capture so far by the Tangerines has been striker Nicky Clark coming from Dunfermline on a free transfer.The former Queen of the South and Rangers man has scored 29 goals in his last 62 matches in the Championship and is tasked with being Csaba’s main goal threat.Also in is former Ross County striker Craig Curran.The battling forward has never been prolific but his job will be to provide ammunition for Clark, while knocking in a few himself.James Keatings, too, is still around at Tannadice after a season beset by injury and personal problems. He’ll seem like a new signing if he can rediscover the form that helped Hamilton, Hearts and Hibs gain promotion to the top flight.Verdict: Looking good up top.Overall: With just 18 first-team players on the books, work is obviously still to be done but initial signs look promising. title: Casual attitude proves a winner for Fortrose cafe
story: &nbspA BLACK Isle cafe has been named Scotland' best choice for casual dining at the third Scottish Hospitality Awards.Fortrose Cafe won the north casual dining title at the awards ceremony at the Crowne Plaza Glasgow Hotel, before going on to beat the three other regional winners to the overall Scottish title.Owner Janet Gray admitted that even when she looked at the official winners photographs from the night, she found it hard to believe they had won both the local and Scottish titles."It came as a complete surprise," she said."The competition was really strong in the north finals. We&rsquore not yet four years old and just a small cafe and we were up against some quite well established opposition."Then to get the national award after that was unbelievable. We are just completely delighted."The Black Isle had another winner in Old Drynie House Bed &amp Breakfast, Kilmuir, which was named north Bed &amp Breakfast of the year.Husband and wife owner-operators Alasdair and Deirdre Mackenzie said they were thrilled to have won, especially given the high quality of the nominees."We started out a few years ago, blessed with an outstanding property," they said."We&rsquove built on that very solid foundation and very much believe that guests coming to our home are part of our family for as long as they are here."The Stables Restaurant and Grill in Fort William also claimed a national title winning both the Scottish and north restaurant of the year.Tigh na Sgiath Country House Hotel in Dulnain Bridge competed the line up of Highland winners by claiming the north hotel award.The Scottish Hospitality Awards 2018 acknowledged the success of Scotland' hospitality sector, from pubs and restaurants to festivals and family attractions, with the winners chosen by members of the general public.The black tie event, hosted by STV radio presenter Zara Janjua, attracted around 200 guests and finalists and also raised funds for charity partner, The Well Foundation.Friday 8 Jun 2018 4:37 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Council plea to ministers for money
story: &nbspCOUNCIL chiefs urgently want &pound180 million extra government funding to improve Highland roads maintained by the local authority.They are telling the UK Treasury and Scottish Government that "just to maintain the road network in its current state, where it gets no better or worse" would require &pound21.7 million annual investment "not including bridges or footways".The figures feature in a four-page plea which also begs for urgent additional funding for schools.The council' independent-led administration reminds the respective governments that, in an age of ever tighter purse strings, it has to manage 4200 miles of roads, more than 2000 bridges and culverts and 100 car parks.The plea stated: "In 2011, we had the 11th best road network in Scotland &ndash we are now seventh worst in 25th place".It argues that it has only&nbsp &pound6.4 million per year &ndash a third of the required funding &ndash available for road resurfacing.The document stated the council cannot afford to further increase the proportion of our revenue budget spent on the network while having the fourth highest debt of Scotland' 32 councils, currently standing at &pound836.7 million.It stated the 2018/19 Scottish Government grant is &pound41 million, of which &pound9.6 million is needed for three flood prevention schemes &ndash and the remaining &pound31.4 million is needed to support all other council assets.The administration highlights the fact that it has the largest number of schools &ndash 204 &ndash and 12 are currently over capacity.Asked how worthwhile the approach to the two governments was, Highland Council leader Margaret Davidson said: "We are a special case. We&rsquove got the most roads and schools and most of them in the poorest condition. That' nobody' fault, that' our geography."She expected both governments to insist that grant support has risen year on year &ndash something the council has consistently disputed.A spokeswoman for the Scottish Government said: "Highland Council has had more money this year from the Scottish Government despite UK government cuts to our budget. It will receive over &pound487 million Scottish Government funding.This is &pound17.1 million more to support services compared to last year taken together with the decision to increase their council tax by three per cent. The local government needs-based funding formula takes into account a number of factors such as rural and island communities, as well as road length and number of school pupils."A spokesman for the UK Treasury said: "We&rsquove helped make the Scottish Parliament one of the most powerful devolved bodies in the world and they have a full range of tax powers to raise funds."Friday 8 Jun 2018 4:37 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Flying the flag for equality for women
story: &nbspAN eye-catching banner made by a group of women in Inverness will take centre stage in a mass procession this weekend to celebrate the centenary of British women being given the right to vote.Members of Highland Multicultural Friends joined forces with a Merkinch craft group to create the artwork which will be carried through the streets of Edinburgh.&nbsp&nbspThe parade, which takes place on Sunday, coincides with others in London, Cardiff and Belfast involving tens of thousands of women.&nbspThe Inverness banner is one of just 100 which have been specially commissioned by 14-18 Now, the UK' arts programme for the World War I centenary, in conjunction with public art producer, Artichoke.It is intended to echo the suffrage movement, voicing women' contemporary hopes and concerns.The two groups involved in its creation were Common Threads &ndash part of Highland Multicultural Friends &ndash and Blazing Needles of Merkinch.Common Threads&nbspis an informal friendship and support group for women from different cultural backgrounds who share a common interest in handiwork ranging from embroidery and patchwork to knitting and crochet.It meets weekly at the Cameron Youth Centre in Planefield Road.Blazing Needles, formed under the now defunct&nbsp Arts in Merkinch organisation, meets weekly at the Bike Shed in Grant Street.Project co-ordinator Catherine MacNeil said the women were delighted with the completed artwork which was created with the help of a professional artist."They wanted to make it clear that they were women from the Highlands," she said."They also wanted it to show that while this is a celebration of women getting the vote there is still a long way to go."Words such as equality, diversity and compassion feature on the banner."These are things which they feel we are still working towards &ndash and not just for women," she said.The project brought together a broad range of women,&nbsp some of whom came to the Highlands from countries where equality is still a dream rather than a reality."Every woman is different," Ms MacNeil said."They all brought something different to the project."They all had their own perspective which added to the dialogue because of their own life experiences."She also felt it had enabled new links and friendships to be formed."I think the main thing they enjoyed was that it was a collaboration," she said."It was not just one group which meets regularly &ndash it was two groups coming together."They enjoyed meeting new people from the other group."They also enjoyed the opportunity to work with a professional artist who helped them to develop new ideas. They found that really positive."They really liked the fact they were all able to have input in the design process right from the beginning to the final piece."The artist allocated to work with the women was Heidi Soos.Based in Inverness, the textile artist is behind Highland Fairy which specializes in creating one-off, customized, recycled vintage garments and accessories.Sunday' parades around the UK will see tens of thousands of women and girls walking&nbsp together wearing colours of either green, white or violet.The intention is that the processions will be choreographed to form a living, moving suffragette flag.Friday 8 Jun 2018 4:38 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Good riddance Announcement due over future of castle and Upper Bridge Street
story: &nbspIT&rsquoS the news all of Inverness has been waiting for.A major announcement is expected which could pave the way for one of the city' most notorious eyesores to be redeveloped, bringing a massive boost to the Highland capital.Important news about the ownership of parts of the much-derided concrete blocks in Upper Bridge Street will be announced by Highland Council next week.The council' hierarchy was staying tight-lipped about the plans until the official announcement &ndash expected on Monday.But the Courier understands that the council has taken steps to simplify the complicated ownership of the buildings.The announcement will also reveal the future of Inverness Castle and it is understood the two are linked.The international class visitor attraction promised for the castle should finally be unveiled after months of discussions.Currently the castle houses the courts, but these are being relocated to a purpose-built &pound30 million justice centre under construction on land beside Burnett Road Police Station.The castle and Upper Bridge Street buildings are key components of the Courier' "Reinvent the City" campaign.It is thought a number of alternatives have been discussed to decide the type of visitor attraction the castle should hold.Highland planning director Stuart Black would not comment but has previously said: "The aim is to create an international class visitor attraction to celebrate the spirit of the Highlands."It will also act as a catalyst for wider regeneration of Inverness city centre as a gateway for Highland tourism."Friday 8 Jun 2018 4:38 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Historic Abertarff House aims to open to the public
story: &nbspTHE public could be given a chance to peek behind the doors of one of Inverness' oldest buildings this summer.Abertarff House, which is more than 400 years old, has recently undergone exterior conservation work by the National Trust for Scotland (NTS).The charity has now submitted a planning application to Highland Council to allow limited access for visitors between July and October.If this proves successful, the NTS may consider opening the ground floor at other times of the year as a showcase for other trust sites and exhibitions around the Highlands.Clea Warner, regional general manager for the NTS, is pleased the plans are moving forward to open up the building &ndash the city' oldest non-religious edifice &ndash to the public."Given the property' central location and people' interest in it as the city' oldest secular building, it' a great opportunity to give people the chance to peek behind the front door of this important part of the Highlands&rsquo heritage, for the first time in many years," she said."We want to use the space to share stories of the Highlands, especially focusing on the places which are protected by our charity."Located in Church Street,the two-and-a-half storey Abertarff House, which dates from 1593, was built for the Frasers of Lovat family.After Colonel Archibald Fraser' death in 1815 it passed to Archibald Thomas Frederick Fraser. It was acquired by the Commercial Bank of Scotland in the 19th century and gifted to the NTS in 1963.Since then it has been used for various purposes including as&nbspthe headquarters for An Comunn Gaidhealach, the NTS regional headquarters and Highland Council' office base for Scotland' Homecoming Festival.The NTS is also hoping to recruit volunteers to help with the running of Abertarff House when it opens."Shifts will be for three hours at a time, so we are hoping that this will appeal to local residents who want to support the trust and all that we do for the love of Scotland," Ms Warner said.Anyone interested in volunteering should contact Margaret Ferguson via&nbsp mferguson@nts.org.uk or telephone her on 01463 732621.Friday 8 Jun 2018 4:38 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: No date yet for work to start on city eyesore
story: &nbspA QUESTION mark is hanging over a start date on work to remove a fire-damaged building blighting Inverness city centre, despite previous reassurances it would be as early as this month.Since the Eastgate Hostel went up in flames in April 2013, there has been increasing frustration over a lack of visible action at the site, which remains swathed in scaffolding,Hopes were raised in March when the owners lodged a planning application to remove the scaffolding and demolish the remaining building ahead of a rebuild.At the time a spokesman said that, if approved, work would start as early as June.But it has now emerged discussions are still on-going between Highland Council officials and the owners in a bid to resolve unforeseen issues.Concerns have also been raised by the council' building conservation and environment officer that the proposed rebuild is lower than the original.Nearby businesses are fed-up at the lack of progress.Chiropodist Jim Crawford, whose practice is in Stephen' Brae, said it was "beyond belief"."If it doesn&rsquot start by the end of June, I think there are real problems and the council should take it over," he said."It has lasted far too long. There always seems to be some excuse which is holding it back."Barber Greg Dodds, of For Men Only, was also frustrated at the lack of information."It seems ridiculous," he said.City centre manager David Haas said talks with the agents were progressing "constructively" but declined to comment on a possible start date."There are a number of issues relating to permission we are working through with council officials and the agent," he said.It has emerged that the council' principal officer for building conservation and environment, Andrew Puls, has raised concerns on conservation grounds regarding the proposed rebuild.In response to the application for the proposed demolition, he states the proposed replacement building is one storey lower and would not "preserve or enhance the character and appearance of the conservation area".A statement issued by two of the site owners, Mr Ali and Mr Cheng, states that "regrettably" unforeseen issues meant the scaffolding would not now be removed in June as originally envisaged.However it also claims that "a new way forward" being investigated should ultimately lead to a much speedier rebuild of the fire damaged building as well as allowing the owners to deal with various matters which had arisen from the recent planning application.Friday 8 Jun 2018 4:38 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Ugliest buildings in Inverness to be redeveloped and castle converted
story: &nbsp&nbspA "ONCE in a generation" opportunity for Inverness has been grasped by Highland Council as it has confirmed plans to buy the ugly office blocks in Upper Bridge Street which have blighted the riverside for years.The Inverness Courier revealed exclusively last week how redevelopment of the site will form part of a bigger plan to create a major new tourist attraction at Inverness Castle once the courts transfer to the new justice centre in Longman Road next year.The local authority confirmed&nbspon Monday&nbspthat it has put together an ambitious "&pound5 million-plus" bid to buy the office blocks and the public will be consulted over what will go in their place.A deal is about to be signed with property firm Inverness Estates which currently owns the two 1960s buildings and retail outlets underneath.The sale price is commercially sensitive at the moment, but is expected to be disclosed at the end of the month.Highland Council already owns the neighbouring museum block.It has branded the project "Inverness Castle &ndash spirit of the Highlands" and it will feature information and stories about the Highlands, with the aim of inspiring people to visit other parts of the region. It will also incorporate the North tower, which has been open to the public as a viewing platform for more than a year and Inverness Museum and Art Gallery.Locals and tourists can also look forward to new galleries which will host national and international exhibitions, displays celebrating the creativity and beauty of the Highlands as well as "retail and catering" which showcase the best of what the region has to offer.&nbspA new hotel could also be created as part of the makeover.The project is to be part-funded by &pound1.5 million from the &pound15 million Scottish Government contribution to the Inverness-Highland City-Region Deal.The remainder will involve hefty borrowing by the council although it said it would benefit from the rents of the various businesses in the existing buildings.Speaking at the castle Rural Economy Secretary Fergus Ewing, co-chairman of the steering group overseeing the castle redevelopment, said the investment would support economic growth and create a "sustainable, viable and must-see attraction to celebrate the spirit of the Highlands".He added: "It will create a once in a generation opportunity for future redevelopment for the city and the Highlands to create something of high architectural value &ndash precisely the opposite of the existing buildings."Equally thrilled council leader Margaret Davidson said: "This has been a long-held ambition."It will help us achieve our vision for this iconic site and Inverness Castle' place as part of a range of tourism assets this region has to offer."Highland planning director Stuart Black confirmed the purchase price was "over &pound5 million", adding: "We&rsquore still in final discussions with the owner but it will be agreed by the end of June and then we&rsquoll release the purchase price."He said the options for the site were to renovate, to redevelop partially &ndash perhaps by removing the upper deck &ndash or what he termed "comprehensive redevelopment".Project manager Graham Watson, of High Life Highland, said: "It' a one-off opportunity for Inverness to really look at how it see its future for Castlehill."The attraction envisaged for the castle will promote the Highlands' "creativity, wellbeing, culture, heritage and natural environment".Friday 8 Jun 2018 4:38 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Yellow peril told to look the other way
story: &nbspTRAFFIC wardens have been ordered not to slap fines on motorists in an Inverness&nbspstreet &ndash because the parking signs are invalid and council workers are too busy fixing potholes to find time to take them down.The "yellow peril" has been instructed to turn a blind eye on Greig Street until a maintenance team can get round to putting up correct signage.The move has left B&ampB owners scratching their heads wondering how they can convince their guests to ignore the signs and assure them they will not get a ticket."Surely the council can do better than that," said Acer Glen Guest House owner Stephen Bowsher."I can quite believe they&rsquore busy fixing potholes but are they really expecting me to turn around to a guest and say &lsquoI know what the signs say but that' OK, you can just ignore it? People are not going to believe it."The curious situation comes after the council performed a u-turn in September on a controversial decision to restrict parking between 8am and 6pm &ndash even on Sundays.The rules were relaxed to allow parking up to 10am and after 5pm &ndash plus all day Sunday &ndash after guest house owners complained it would damage trade at the central spot.Some B&ampBs have racked up bad reviews on Trip Advisor and other websites over the tight parking rules which force guests to get up early and wolf down breakfast so they can shift their cars by 8am to avoid a parking ticket.However, almost a whole year on and the old signs have not yet been replaced leaving guest house owners "absolutely livid" and complaining that they have to deal with grouchy guests who leave bad comments on key tourist trap websites.The council' response is to tell traffic wardens to pay no heed to the signs &ndash because it does not know long it will take to free up manpower to change them.The short-term "solution" has really got the goat of guest house owners. "I feel like taking a pen and just going around and changing the signs," said Arafeh Alashi, who runs The Quaich B&ampB on Greig Street."It would save money and time. I could nip to B&ampQ and get stickers and change the times. That would take all of 20 minutes."Mr Arafeh received a phone call from the council just over a fortnight ago "apologising and promising me that the signage was going to be installed within a week or two".He added: "I&rsquom very upset about this. I know the council is trying but they&rsquore not trying hard enough. It' one street, four signs, it' not exactly the whole of the city centre."Kenneth Mackay who owns nine-bed Melrose Villa at 35 Kenneth Street, said: "The council promised us nine months ago they were going to do this. We are absolutely fuming. People are spending a lot of money here and the council are not helping us one iota. They&rsquore destroying all attempts to reinvent the city centre with this palaver."The council said the signs cost about a tenner each but it was struggling to free up workers to put up signs as they were "extremely busy" making road repairs.A council spokeswoman said: "We are waiting for operatives to be available to change the signs."The priority is the maintenance of the roads infrastructure and they are extremely busy on this task therefore we wait for them to be made available to change the signs. When the staff are available the signs will be changed. In the meantime our enforcement team have been instructed not to enforce before 10am and after 5pm."Friday 8 Jun 2018 4:38 PM&nbsp&nbsp

title: how much is europa league group stage worth to aberdeen
story: Aberdeen will bid for a Europa League group stage jackpot of more than £3 million next season.That figure could be much larger, even before television and gate revenue.UEFA have confirmed the prize fund for the Europa League and it is 50% up on last season.The Dons begin their quest to reach the lucrative group stages for the first time under boss Derek McInnes when they enter at the second qualifying round on Thursday July 26.Former Dons striker Darren Mackie scored the “£1 million goal” in the 1-1 draw with Dnipro in Ukraine in October 2007 to secure a spot in the then UEFA Cup groups.Reaching that level is worth millions more to the Dons should they achieve their target.McInnes insists having European football can help lure new signings to Pittodrie for the upcoming season.He has already secured midfielder Chris Forrester from Peterborough on a three-year-deal for a fee of £200,000.McInnes said: “When talking to players I always say there is the likelihood of European football with Aberdeen.“Having that confirmed for next season can only help when trying to sign players.”The basic cash reward for qualifying for the 48-team group stages is 2.92m Euros (£2.57m).There are added payments in the lead-up to the groups with prizes of 260,000 Euros (£229,000) for progressing past the second qualifying round and a further 280,000 Euros (£247,000) for moving beyond the third qualifying round.Reaching the group stages brings a basic combined total of £3,046,000.However, the group stages also bring an added coefficient share of 84m Euros divided between the 48 teams depending on each side’s UEFA ranking.The club ranked lowest of the 48 teams will receive 71,430 Euros (£62,890)One share, ie 71,430 Euros, will be added to every rank so that highest-ranked team will receive 48 shares (3.42m Euros).If, for example, Aberdeen were the 38th-ranked team they would pocket 10 times 71,430 – 714,300 Euros (£628,900).Further cash bonuses come through performance in the groups with a payment of 570,000 Euros (£502,000) per win and 190,000 Euros (£167,000) per draw.The Reds will discover their second qualifying round opponents on Tuesday June 19 when the draw is made at the UEFA headquarters in Nyon, Switzerland.Aberdeen have exited at the third qualifying round for the last four successive seasons.McInnes’ side have lost out to Apollon Limassol (Cyprus), NK Maribor (Slovenia), Kairat Almaty (Kazakhstan) and Real Sociedad (Spain) at that stage.

title: counsellors sought in bid to help youngsters
story: A children&#8217s charity has issued an urgent appeal for new volunteers so it can help more young people.Aberdeen’s Childline currently has 145 counsellors, but needs more than 50 to reach out to youngsters who need someone to talk to.Childline volunteer Siobhain Leith, 23, was presented with a Saltire Award by Aberdeen Central MSP Kevin Stewart earlier this year for her commitment to volunteering.She said: “I started at Childline just over a year ago. I saw an advert from Childline founder Esther Rantzen and my mum and I looked at it and knew it was the right thing for me.“I love being able to give something back and helping other people who are going through tough times.”The city’s organisation is hosting a volunteer information meeting on June 21 between 6-8pm at Ruby Place in Aberdeen.Those interested in finding out more on how to take part in the open day or what Childline does are asked to contact 01224 973 030.

title: organisation to help raise charity technology funds
story: Staff from the north-east branch of a building society are helping in the firm’s goal to raise £250,000 in two years for charity.Leeds Building Society is hoping to raise the money for Samaritans in order to help enhance the charity’s technology so its volunteers can move faster between phone, email and chat responses, and Aberdeen workers are playing their part in fundraising with a number of bake sales and cycling events.More than £40,000 has been raised three months into the project by colleagues and members through a number of events.Samaritans CEO Ruth Sutherland said: “We’re delighted Leeds Building Society colleagues and members voted to support our technology project.&#8220The money raised will ensure we remain relevant and accessible to people’s changing needs and help us respond quickly to anyone who is feeling overwhelmed.“It’s so inspiring to see staff and the public across the country, getting behind the partnership and that so many creative and fun-filled fundraising activities are being put on to support us.”

title: teacher recruitment change successful
story: A north-east council&#8217s revamped teacher recruitment process has led to more people opting to work in the area.Previously Moray Council’s schools were losing out on teaching staff due to a lengthy interview process which saw schools essentially competing against each other.The time this process took meant many teachers accepted jobs elsewhere.This year the newly-qualified teachers underwent just one interview and were deployed to vacancies across the area within weeks.The new process has meant that 22 newly-qualified teachers will be boosting numbers in Moray’s schools from August.In addition, many were originally from the area and had come back after university to complete their training and start their teaching career on home turf.

title: argyllshire advertiser leader column 24
story: Colin CameronUpdated: 17/05/18, 11:31 amLikeGoogle +1TweetEmailWant to read more?We value our content and our journalists, so to get full access to all your local news updated 7-days-a-week – PLUS an e-edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser – subscribe today for as little as 56 pence per week.We heartily agree with the decision of the Lord Lieutenant to nominate Betty Rhodick to attend the royal wedding.As far as we are aware, no one works harder for Lochgilphead  &#8211 and once Betty puts her mind to something&#8230Betty and Geordie have been the figureheads for the Lochgilphead Armed Forces Day commemorations since they started, but she deserves this recognition not just for this one annual event, but for all she does on our behalf.Enjoy yourself, Betty and Kelly.The renovated Kilmartin Museum is now almost within reach.This is sure to be of great economic benefit to the region when it opens in two years and it is an exciting prospect that will enable the unique heritage of Mid Argyll to be properly showcased.Just what was last weekend&#8217s Scapa festival at Ardkinglas?The answer is probably unique to every individual who attended.
